The portrait is signed: T. Cross sculpsit.
Printer's name from the Pforzheimer Catalogue. "The copy was divided between two compositors. One set-up through sheet S; the other, the remainder"--Pforzheimer Catalogue.
Signatures: pi1 A (-A6-8) B-S; A-F G⁴; A⁴ B-F G1-3 (=A6-8).

"The novella" and "The court begger" each have separate dated title page; register is continuous. "The city wit" (Wing B4866) and "The damoiselle" (Wing B4868) each have separate register and dated title page with "printed by T.R." in imprint. There is no indication that the latter two plays were ever issued separately, though they are sometimes found so (Greg).
"The Novella" identified on UMI microfilm (Early English Books 1641-17700) reel 1773 as wing B4880.
Reproductions of the originals in the British Library and the Harvard University Library.

div.p: THE DAMOISELLE, OR THE NEW ORDINARY.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be ſold at their Shops in Fleet-ſtreet, 1653.

lg.l: OƲR Playmaker (for yet he won't be calld
Author, or Poet) nor beg to be inſtalld
●ir Lawreat) has ſent me out t'invite
●our fancies to a full and cleane delight:
And bids me tell you, That though he be none
Of thoſe, whoſe towring Muſes ſcale the Throne
Of Kings, yet his familiar mirth's as good,
When tis by you approv'd and underſtood.
As if h' had writ ſtrong lines, and had the fate,
Of other Fools for medling with the State.
Readers and Audients make good Playes or Books,
Tis appetite makes Diſhes, tis not Cooks.
But let me tell you, though you have the power,
To kill or ſave; They're Tyrants that devoure,
And Princes that preſerve: He does not ayme,
So much at praiſe, as pardon; nor does claime
Lawrell, but Money; Bayes will buy no Sack,
And Honour fills no belly, cloaths no back.
And therefore you may ſee his maine intent
Is his owne welfare, and your merriment.
Then often come, 'twill make us and him the wetter,
Wee'l drown the faults of this, in one that's better.

list.item: Brookeall, a Gentleman, undone by Vermine.

Freindly, a Templer.
Two Gallants
Oliver,
Ambroſe,

div.head: THE DAMOISELLE, OR, The New Ordinary.

lg.l: _YOU have your Money; full a thou|ſand pound,
Sir Humfrey Dryground.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: And you have my Mortgage.

lg.l: All well and good; all well and good. But, now,
Sir Humfrey Dryground, let me counſell you.
You have already ſpent a faire Eſtate;
A goodly, great eſtate: I do not taunt,
Nor taxe you for't.
Becauſe its pumpt into
The purſes of ſuch wretches as thy ſelfe.
But give me leave, now, fairely to admoniſh
You, to a care, how you do part with this.
You ſpirited men call Money Dirt and Mud.
I ſay it is the Eele.
And you the Mud
That foſter it.
It is an Eele, I ſay,
In ſuch ſleek hands, as yours; from whence it glides—

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Into the Mud, oft-times, from whence it came.

lg.l: I know you doe conceive me. Therefore, Sir,
(As I before was ſaying) Hold it faſt.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: According to the Ballad.

lg.l: Youth keep thy Money faſt,
And tye it in thy Purſe:
For that muſt be thine onely Freind,
For better and for worſe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: So ſo, I ſee it going already.

lg.l: I, to thy comfort. This is the Uſurers Scripture;
And all that they pretend Salvation by:
To give good admonition with their Money;
Though, in their hearts they wiſh the quick ſubverſion
Of all they deal with. This is all they plead
Againſt the curſes of oppreſſed ſoules:
Did not I warne you? Did not I ſay, take heed?
And ſo, and ſo forth. I muſt thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ver
sp.p: You ſay, youle make a venture of this Money.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Yes Mr. Vermine, in a Project, that—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Out upon Projects. Fy fy, out out out.

lg.l: I'm confident ſhall ſet me out of debt,
With you and all the World; and reap, againe,
All, that I formerly have ſowne, with profit.
Sowne! There's a word! Prodigall waſt is ſowing.
We ſhall call Shipwrack, ſhortly, ſowing too.
Heark you Sir Humfrey Dryground, may not I
Be privy to your Project? Will you tell me,
If I gueſſe on it?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: That I will in ſooth.

lg.l: Is 't not to dreine the Goodwins? To be Lord
Of all the Treaſure, buryed in the Sands there?
And have a Million yearely, from the Merchants
To cleer the paſſage.
You have had your blow.
No Sir, my Project is in the behalfe
Of the poor Gentleman, you overthrew.
By the ſtrong hand of Law, Bribes, and oppreſſion;
Brookall: Do you know him Sir? whoſe ſtate you ſuck'd
That wrought him to a poverty that cryes
Your ſinfull Covetiſe up to the heighth;
And renders you the Monſter of our time,
For avarice and cruelty.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: No more of that.

lg.l: You ſhould do well to add a ſum, like this
To his releife: To wave the bitter curſe
That will in time fall on you and your houſe.
O ho! I now remember, you have reaſon.
That Brookall had a Siſter, whom you vitiated
In your wild heat of blood, and then deny'd
Her promis'd Marriage; turnd her off with Childe
A dozen yeares ſince, and ſince that, never heard of▪
Ha! Is't not ſo? Pray, did you know her Sir?
I wiſh I could redeem that ruthfull fault,
By all expiatory meanes: But thy
Inhumane cruelty is inexpiable:
Unleſſe (it comes from Heaven into my heart
To move thee to't) thou tak'ſt a ſpeedy courſe
To give him threefold reſtitution.
Ile put thee in the way. He has a Son,
A hopefull Youth, a Student in the Law,
If his poor Fathers want of means have not
Declined his courſe: Give him thy onely Daughter,
And make his Fathers owne Inheritance
(By thee unrighteouſly uſurpt) her Dowry;
And pray a bleſſing may go with it: And then
Thou mayſt regaine a Chriſtian reputation,
Till age ſhall lead thee to a quiet Grave.
Come, is 't a match? Will you beſtow your Daughter
On Brookalls Son, and make your way to Heaven by't?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: You have your Money.

lg.l: And thou haſt Adders eares
To all ſuch Counſells.
If you break your day
I ſhall thinke of your counſell.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Farewell Vermine.

lg.l: And farewell Dryground.
This parcell of thy Land, Ile keep from wetting: The Mortgage.
Tis not in thee to turne an Acre of it
Into pure Liquor, for a twelve moneths day.
And break that day thy payment, and the Sun
Sets not more ſure, then all this Land is mine.
My Daughter! ha! Can't be in thought of man
To dreame of ſuch a Match? A wretch, a Beggar?
Within there! Where▪s my Girle? What Ally? Ally?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Here Sir—

sp.speaker: Vir.
sp.p: My bleſſing, and good morne: Now heare me Girle.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Now for a Speech—

lg.l: The care of Children's ſuch a ſtartle-braine,
That had I more then one, I ſhould run Wild-cat,
(Then one I mean, to care for) that's thy ſelfe,
My ſober diſcreet Daughter. Note my care,
Pil'd up for thee in maſſy ſums of wealth;
Too weighty for thy weak conſideration
To gueſſe from whence it came, or how together
So layd in mountainous heaps.
It is indeed
As ſtrange to me, as are the ſtony wonders
On Salsbury Plaine to others. But my duty
Perſwades me twas your thrift, and that great bleſſing
That gives increaſe to honeſt Induſtry,
Drawne on it by your prayers and upright life,
That wrought theſe heaps together.
O, Ally Ally,
Tis well if thine with all thy Huſwifry
Can keep 'em ſo. I thanke thee for thy judgement
And charitable thoughts. But—

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: You had other wayes.

lg.l: I ſay, thou art the onely Childe I care for.
Thy Brother (though I loath to call him ſo)
Is, now, an utter ſtranger to my blood;
Not to be nam'd but with my curſe, a Wolfe
That teares my very bowells out.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Your Money.

lg.l: A riotous Reprobate, that hath conſum'd
His laſt, already, of my meanes and bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: But he yet may be turn'd Sir.

lg.l: Out oth' Compter!
May he be ſo, doſt think? Could I but dream
His Creditors, that have him faſt, could be
So idly mercifull, or that his youthfull Ghing
Could ſtretch, to get him out, Ile lay, my ſelfe,
An Action on him weightier, then the ſtrength
Of all their poor abilities could lift:
His Jacks, his Toms, his Nams, Nolls, Gills, and Nuns,
The roaring fry of his Blade-brandiſhing mates
Should not releaſe his Carcaſſe: If they did,
I'de force him to a tryall for his life,
For the two hundred Peices that he pilfred.
Out of my Counting-houſe. He ſhall up.
I will not forfeit my obedience Sir,
To urge againſt your Juſtice, onely I crave
Your leave to grieve, that I have ſuch a Brother.
Thou ſhalt defie the name of Brother in him,
My onely, onely Childe; and but in one command
Obey me further, all my eſtate is thine,
Tis that I cald thee for.
I do not crave
More, then your daily bleſſing; but deſire
To know what youle impoſe upon my duty.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt, and ſtile thy ſelfe a Lady by't.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Now Love defend me from the man I feare.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: This day Ile match thee to a matchleſſe Knight.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: The Weſterne Kight Sir, that was here laſt Term?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Even he, this day he comes to Towne.

lg.l: Would I
Were out on't firſt. A matchleſſe Knight Aſide.
Indeed, and ſhall be matchleſſe ſtill for me.
I like thoſe bluſhes well: I read his welcome
Upon her cheeks.
Sir, I have heard, he has
But little Land.
But he has Money Girle
Enough to buy the beſt Knights Land, that is
A ſelling Knight, in the Weſt part of England.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: He's well in yeares.

lg.l: A luſty Batchelor of two and fifty,
With, O, the husbandry thats in him.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: How came he by his Knighthood? Coſt it no|thing?

lg.l: No: He was one oth' Cobbe-Knights in the throng,
When they were dubd in Cluſters.
Sir, the Knight,
That you expect this day, is come to Towne.
His man has brought's Portmantue.
Fetch the Man.
The welcomſt man alive is come to Towne.
Ally, my Girle, my Daughter, Lady Bride!
What title ſhall I give thee? Now beſtirr you,
I know his thrift, he has rid hard to day
To ſave his Dinner Enter Wat diſguiſed like a Countrey Serving man.
Welcome honeſt freind.
And how does the right worſhipful Sir Amphilus?
My Maſter is in health Sir, prayſ'd be Go—
A little weary, or ſo, as I am of my carriage,
Which I muſt not lay down, but in the hands
Of your owne Worſhip.
Tis of weight and lock'd: I gueſſe the worth,
And warrant him the ſafety under theſe Keyes.
But where's thy Maſter?
At his Inne in Holborne
Telling a little with the Hoſt, till I
Bring word from you.
No, I will run to him
My ſelfe: you ſhall ſtay here▪ his Chamber
Fitted againſt he comes, Ally, beſtirr you,
And thinke no paines your trouble on this day,
To morrows Sun ſhall light your Wedding way.
Unleſſe ſome unexpected Fate releive me,
I ſhall be hurried to my endleſſe ruine.
You are ſad, me thinks, young Miſtreſſe, I can tell you,
My Maſter, when he comes, will make you merry.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: How? As he is a Foole?

lg.l: No: But as he has
The ſoule of mirth and Muſick at command;
Money, the all-rejoycing ſpirit; that
Hee'l make you merry with: Nor that alone,
But Dignity, which Women priſe 'bove money,
You are a Lady by't: Mark that. And if
He has a weakneſſe, which you reckon folly;
It laies you open way to Soveraignty;
The thing which is of moſt eſteem. You'll be
His Lady Regent; rule all his, and him.
This Fellow talkes not like a Serving-man:
A forty ſhilling wages Creature, but
Some diſguiſ'd ſpokeſ-man. What may be the trick o'nt?
You cannot, in th' eſtate you are, imagine
What tis to be a Wife to ſuch a man.
No more then you perceive the paines you looſe
In fooling for him thus. But ſpare your breath,
And take this briefe taſt of his Entertainment.
Firſt know, that J do know the man you ſpeak of,
To be a covetous Miſer; old and fooliſh.
Not worth in my eſtimation the worſt Meale
That ever he himſelfe paid three pence for.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Who do you mean? Sir Amphilus my Knight.

lg.l: Yes Squire, J know him and his qualities;
The waies he got his Wealth by, caſuall Matches;
Of forty, fifty, and ſometimes a hundred
For one. When bounteous Fortune (ſeldome failing
Men of his Brain) caſt all into his mouth,
The Gudgeon gap▪d for. And how ſlight a thing
It is, for ſuch baſe Worldlings to be rich?
That ſtudy nothing but to ſcrape and ſave.
That have no Faith, but in their ready money,
Nor love to Worldly pleaſures above thoſe
Poor Coblers uſe.
Cheap Whores, and Duck-hunting:
There▪s his delight indeed.
J hate to think of of ſuch a Dunghill Scarab.
A water-Dog Knight!
But Wedlock, to his age, will bring him home
To choicer pleaſures, and abandon ſuch.
His Age is fit for nothing, but to rock
Anothers Child; and to rejoyce through Spectacles,
At the ſtrong Gueſſe he has, it is his owne.
You ſlight him ſtrangely yet: but when you ſee
Him, and his weighty reaſons to confute you.—
J will nor weigh, nor ſee him, or his reaſons.
And if thou ow'ſt him ſo much Service, tell him;
Go back and tell him ſtrait: ſave him the end
Of his intended Journey. For to come
Hither, will be to drive me hence. And tell
My Father, ere he ſhall enforce me, take him;
Ile flye into the Armes of one he hates.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Are you in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Yes, by all my hopes.

lg.l: Theſe are the armes that muſt receive thee then.
Nay, be not frighted Siſter; look, tis J.
Beſhrew me but J am. How got you hither?
Could not the Compter hold you?
So it ſeems,
My Virtue was not to be ſo obſcur'd.
Noble Sir Humphrey Dryground, Siſter, was
My franck Infranchiſer. O, J have wonders
To tell thee Siſter. Thou muſt go with me.
But firſt, lend me ſome money. Borrow ſome;
(And let it be a good Summe) of my Father,
Now in his abſence. Come, ſupply, ſupply
My Pockets and thine owne. For we muſt hence.
Th'art made for ever, Siſter. Quick, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this?

lg.l: Twill be too long to tell it here.
The Raſcall foole, to whom my Father gives thee,
Is come to Towne: And ſhould he now ſurpriſe thee,
Here in my Fathers power, thy ſtrength might faile thee.
Be therefore at a ſure Guard. O, Sir Humphrey,
How are my Siſter and my ſelfe bound to thee,
That plotteſt this eſcape. Diſpatch good Ally,
And heare thee reſt by th' way.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Why? Wither? What's the matter?

lg.l: Say thou will have that Coxcomb, Ile but kill thee,
And leave the here: And all my care is over.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Ile ſooner dye then have him.

lg.l: Why do you not ſhun him then? O, ſweet Sir Humphrey,
Is thy care ſlighted thus, in my delivery?
In my diſguiſe? In ſending out my Father
On Tom-fooles Errant? While a Coach is ſent
To the back-doore here; All to ſave my Siſter,
My thankleſſe Siſter here, from worſe then Rape.

sp.speaker: Ali
sp.p: Why, whither would you have me?

lg.l: But hard-by.
But till the Wilde-fire of my Fathers Paſſion
Shall be run out. Slid, J had eene forgot.
Beare money with us, Siſter; pretty ſtore.
Who knowes occaſions? Let him keep in pawne
My rich Portmantue for't.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: There's ſome good ſtuff in't.

lg.l: More then hee▪ll thank me for. Wee'll talke i'th' Coach
In, in, and furniſh; & ſo through the Garden,
And, whirre, we are gone. If we ſhould be prevented;
By this good ſteele, if J but heare one knock,
Jle make ſure work o▪thee. J can but truſſe for▪t.
There's a faire end on's both. And what will he
Do with his money then? Look how thou ſtandſt.
Jf you reſpect your Father, or the Dog-Maſter,
To be your Husband, better then me, then take
You your owne courſe: Mine ſhall be known next Seſ|ſions.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Better then you, don't you reſpect your Father Better then me?

lg.l: No, if J do, let me be hang'd for nothing:
And that would anger any man I think.
'Slid, thou and J had one Mother, (which
We both take after) ſo had not he and we.
And he takes after no body, that J know.
He loves a ſtranger better then's owne Childe:
And that mans money, better then that man,
The Devill 'bove all J think. Thou doſt not know
What Coales we ſtand on.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Who ſhall look toth'houſe?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Wilt looſe thy ſelfe with keeping that? Is that All now? Away, away.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Y'are a precious Brother.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: ALL this needs not Sir Humphrey.

lg.l: Do but heare patiently, and do your pleaſure.
J go not about to ſtop your courſe, Mr. Bumpſey.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Nor J yours, Sir Humphrey; Nor your Sonnes here; Nor his Wifes there: Onely this Gen|tlewoman, in mine owne right J may be bold withall, while you depart my houſe, if you may be intreated, ſo. Is not this right? Is not this plain?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Yet heare his Worſhip ſpeak, good Bump.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p:
Good Whirly, what can his Worſhip ſpeak? Or your wiſdome twatle for him, in this Cauſe; that J do not underſtand already? Has not his Sonne wedded our Daughter? How directly, or indi|rectly,
who meddles with his match? Nay more, has he not bedded her? How, directly or indirect|ly, who meddles with that either? Let him have and hold, poſſeſſe (Hmh.) and enjoy; do his worſt, and make his beſt of her, though ſhe be an Heire, J will not ſue him out of her: No, J proteſt; were it Ante Copulam, as it is poſt, J would not croſſe em. Is not this right and plaine enough.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: But good Mr. Bumpſey, Brother Bumpſey, I would call you—

lg.l: Keep your Brothers and your Goods to your ſelfe, Sir, J have no need of 'em.
You are a Knight, and a man ot Worſhip—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: He will ſpeake all himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: J am a plaine Fellow, and out of debt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: J, let him run on.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: J ſought none of your Allyance, J—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Has he the ſpeed to run beyond himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Yes, and bring himſelfe about, J warrant you.

lg.l: Nor to be joyned with houſes of great ſound,
Whoſe noiſe growes from their hollow emptineſſe.
J could have matcht my Daughter here, that was,
But now a Barronetteſſe in Reverſion,
To a ſubſtantiall Heire of two faire Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Perhaps no Gentleman.

lg.l: Yet honourable, Land-Lordſhip's reall honour,
Though in a Tradeſ-man Son: when your faire Titles
Are but the ſhadowes of your Anceſtry;
And you walk in'em, when your Land is gone:
Like the pale Ghoſts of dead Nobilitie.
Ha! Iſt not ſo? Is not this right and plaine?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Yes like the priviledge you uſe in your owne houſe here.

lg.l: Nay I come up to you now Sir Humfry Dry|ground;
Up in a point of Chivalry. You are a Knight,
A Baronet to boot: Your ſon is like
T'inherit that deare paid-for title, but
(Youle give me leave to uſe my plainneſſe)

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Freely.

lg.l: Your ſon (I ſay) is Heire to your bought honour.
Which may hereafter Ladifie my Daughter:
But where▪s the Land you once were Lord of? Ha!
The goodly Cornfields, Medows, Woods, and Paſtures,
That muſt maintain the Houſe, the Gownes, the Coach,
With all by complements of Horſes, Hawks, and Hounds.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Now hees in.

lg.l: Where be the Parks, the Warrens, Herds, and Flocks?
Beſides the Gardens, Orchards, Walks, and Fiſh-ponds?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: For that heare me.

lg.l: Ods pitty, give me leave,
You, that had all theſe once, in three faire Lordſhips,
To be wrought on, and tonyed out of all,
But a ſmall pittance of Trois Cents per Annum,
By Providence intayld upon the Heire,
(Or thad had waſted too) which now maintaines you,
In a proportion of Smoak, and Sack,
To waſh your mouth with after, where you live
Confin'd in Milford Lane, or Fullers Rents,
Or who knows where, it skills not—

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Muſt I heare this too.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Now he has almoſt done.

lg.l: Can you (I ſay) think your good husbandry
A lawfull Precedent for your Gameſome ſon
To make my Daughter happy in a Marriage,
Though he had twice my Fortunes?
Now hee's coming:
Beare but with this; and if he offer not
More then you would requeſt, Ile loſe your love.
But here's the ſubſtance of't, you have my Daughter,
Your Son, ſir, has my Daughter, that muſt have,
And ſhall, my whole Eſtate at my Deceaſe;
(No Law exacts it ſooner) This Eſtate
You ſafely may ſuppoſe ten thouſand pounds,
Which J have got by thrifty Induſtry.
Onely one thouſand, J confeſſe, my Wife
Improv'd my Fortune with, Here's the juſt ſumme.
J give her▪ leave to give it to her Daughter:
She may endow her Husband with it. So,
Is not this plaine? Now note me further, ſir;
What J have left is my owne; and you, ſir, may
Which what is theirs take hence your Son & Daughter,
Till you ſhall heare old Bumpſey is deceaſt.
Then let him come, and challenge all—that's left;
Mean time J know my courſe.
Now chop in with him, Mother, you know how apt
Hee is to croſſe you in theſe Moods.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Deare, worthy, honour'd, ſir,

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: ſh●t, ſh't, ſh't; Woman come you with me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: J Bump. Let us go our way, and let them take theirs agods name.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray heare me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: At this time, ſir, he ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Shall not! He ſhall ſure: Ods pity! ſhall not: Are you pleas'd to ſpeak, ſir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: not to offend—

lg.l: Not to a Fiddleſtick. Shall not! Can you ſpeak or not?
If not, pray yell me ſo.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: J married, ſir, your Daughter.

lg.l: You may thank her Mother for't, not me.
Well, will you ſpeake?
J married her in a firme hope to winne
Your Love and favour.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Well.

lg.l: Which, ſince I have not yet; and time muſt worke it,
I would make this my ſuit.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Would I could heare it once.

lg.l: That you would take
With re-acceptance of this thouſand pound
Your Daughter and me into your Family.
And why the thouſand pound; doe's't burn your Fingers?
Give us but meat and lodging for●t: My Father,
Out of his little left Eſtate will give us
A hundred yearely for other neceſſaries.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: With all my heart.

lg.l: And as you finde my regular life deſerve
Your future favour, ſo extend your bounty,
When Age ſhall call upon you to diſpoſe
Of all your faire Poſſeſſions.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Humh! A pretty od ſpeech this! I would I knew The meaning on●t.

lg.l: I mean, Sir, as I ſpeak; that till you finde
Strong probability in me to manage
A good eſtate, you truſt me not with any.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Ha! Is it ſo? Then J come to a point with you.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Marke him now, Sir Humfrey.

lg.l: You look, Sir, in my Daughters right, to have,
After my death, my whole Eſtate, by ſhewing
Me, in my life time, your good husbandry, by husban|ding of nothing:
Y' have tane off halfe my purpoſe; for J meant
To have kept it in my power, whether to leave her
Any, or nothing: And, perhaps (d'yee heare)
By an odd courſe, that J was thinking on
To ha▪ made all nothing ere J dy'd: But now
Halfe of that power Ile put into your hands,
Ile try what you can do with ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Halfe? What meane you halfe?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Even halfe of all J have.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: J hope you will not deal ſo.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: And as he deals with that, Ile uſe the reſt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Pray be adviſ'd.

lg.l: Never by you 'gainſt this:
Ile give him inſtantly the free poſſeſſion
Of halfe J have: Now marke; if you increaſe,
Or keep that halfe, then, doubtleſſe, J ſhall do,
As well with tother for you: If you diminiſh
Or waſte it all, ile do the like with my part.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Husband.

lg.l: Ile do't: Together we will live:
And Ile along with you in your owne courſe,
And, as you play your game, you win or loſe all:
Thrive and ile thrive: Spend you, and J will ſpend:
Save, and Jle ſave; ſcatter, and Ile ſcatter.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: You won't be mad.

lg.l: Ile do't: Let him throw Money
Into the Thames, make Ducks and Drakes with Peices,
Ile do the like: till he has made a match
Or no match of my Daughter: There's the point
And the whole ſubſtance on't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Will you do ſo?

lg.l: Will I? Tis done. Ile make him a good husband,
Or be no husband for him: And ſo ſee
Whats mine, out of the danger of his waſte,
And have ſome ſport too for my Money: Ha!
I love to do theſe things.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Nay, but in one thing, Bump. let me adviſe you.

lg.l: In nothing `gainſt this courſe, good whirly: no,
Tis ſo ſet downe. I know I ſhall be counted
An odde old humorous Cockſcombe for't by ſome:
But the truth is, I love to do theſe things:
And ſo God gi yee joy.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Ile take my leave Sir.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Not ſo I hope, Sir Humfry.

lg.l: I have buſineſſe,
And go well ſatisfied with this agreement:
And, Val. take briefly this my Charge: You are now
A Husband, be a good one: Y'have my bleſſing.
But (heark you) do you remember 'gainſt the evening?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: All Sir, all: I have ſpread my Nets already.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Sir, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: At your pleaſure Sir.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Ile ſhortly viſit you.

lg.l: At your own good time Sir- Exit Drygr.
Theſe ſhall ſtay here, Ile blindfold them with Money,
And by a new way try, if they can grope
The right way into th' World. Come your way.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: ANd why this Gullery to me, good Ambroſe?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: J ſwear J am ſerious, and you may may beleeve it.

lg.l: What, that there can be in the World an Aſſe
(Wert thou a fool to credit it) that would keep
A Houſe, by way of publike Ordinary,
For faſhionable Gueſts, and curious ſtomacks;
The daintieſt Pallats, with rich Wine and Chear;
And all for nothing, but alls paid and welcome?
Vall Dryground told it me, whoſe truth deſerves
So well my credit, that, prove you it falſe,
Ile pay all Ord'naries and Taverne reckonings
You ſhall be at this twel'moneth.
J have heard
Of all the Mockeries, the Ape, the Ram, the Hornes,
The Goat, and ſuch tame Monſters, whom poor wits
Have ſent wiſe Tradeſmen to, as to a Knight,
A Lord, or forrain Prince; to be his Mercer,
His Taylor, Semſter, Millener, or Barber:
When thoſe, that have beene mock'd, ſtill ſent their Neighbours,
Till halfe the City have bee fool-found. Ha!
Iſt not ſome ſuch poor trick?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Here comes my Author.

lg.l: O Mr. Bridegroom, that ſtole the wealthy match!
How got you looſe ſo ſoone? J thought you had beene
tyed up by the Loines, like a Monkey to the Bed-poſt,
for a fortnight at the leaſt. How does old Bumpſey, that
Freecoſt Drunkard, thy mad Father-in-Law, take thy
ſtolne Marriage? I am ſure he knows on't.
He found's abed laſt night i'th' nick, as we ſay.
But we are peec'd this morning.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Then he wrangled it out, of himſelfe. J know his ſingular humour.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What has he gi'n thee?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Halfe, of all he has.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: How?

lg.l: On this Condition, that, if J ſave
That halfe untill he dyes, the reſt is mine too.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What if thou ſpendſt thy halfe?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Heel ſpend the tother; and the ſame way, hee ſweares.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Hee'l nere keep Covenant.

lg.l: He tell you how he runs at waſte already,
This morning the French Taylor brought a Gowne home,
Of the faſhion, for my Wife. He bought one
Streight, ready made, for his old Gentlewoman,
That never wore ſo rich in all her life.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: O brave old woman! How will ſhee carry it?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I ſpoke but of a Coach, and he beſpoke one.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Wonder upon wonder! Nam was telling one Before thou cam'ſt.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What the new Ordnary?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Doſt know the man that keeps it?

lg.l: They call him Osbright.
A brave old Blade. He was the Preſident
Of the Can-quarrelling Fraternity,
Now calld the Roaring Brotherhood, thirty years ſince,
But now grown wondrous civill, free, and hoſpitable,
Having had ſomething fallen to him, as it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: That Osbright has been dead theſe many years.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It was given out ſo: But he lived beyond Sea.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: There▪s ſome ſtrange plot in't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O thou pollitick Noll.

lg.l: Judge thy ſelfe, Val, what can the myſtery be?
He tells me there's no Gaming, ſo no Cheating;
Nor any other by-way of expence,
By Bawdry, or ſo, for privy profit.
Such a ſuſpition were a ſin. But now
I will unfold the Riddle to you. This feaſting
Has been but for three dayes, and for great perſons,
That are invited, and to be prepar'd
To venture for a prize. This very night
There will be ſome great Rifling for ſome Jewell,
Or other rare Commodity, they ſay.
I cannot nam't: tis twenty pound a man.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Is not that gaming prithee?

lg.l: Thats to come:
But, hitherto, nor Dice, nor Cards▪ nor Wench,
Is ſeen ith' houſe, but his owne, onely Daughter.
O! has he Daughter there? Mark that Nam.
No gaming ſayſt thou? Ods me, and they play not
At the old Game of old there, I dare—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I dare be ſworne thou doſt 'em wrong.

lg.l: Shees too ftale, is ſhee?
Tis above twenty yeares ſince he went over,
And was reported dead (they ſay) ſoon after,
In France, I take it: But, then, it ſeemes, he lived,
And got this Damſell there? Is ſhe French borne?
Yes, ſhe was born and bred there: And can ſpeak
Engliſh but brokenly. But, for French behaviour,
Shees a moſt compleat Damoiſelle, and able
To give inſtructions to our Courtlieſt Dames.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Shee muſt be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: But ſee who here comes firſt.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Thou haſt undone me Villaine.

lg.l: Out alas!
I was as ignorant of the deceit,
As your owne innocent worſhip ever was
Of cozening any man of Land or Living.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Was ever man ſo curſed in his Children!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Tis the wretch Vermine.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What makes he here, trow, in the Temple Walks?

lg.l: What ſhould he do elſewhere, when Law's his Lechery.
The Devils itch dry up his marrow for't.
He undid a worthy Gentleman I know.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: I, Brookall, thruſting him out of his Land.

lg.l: Hee's fitted with an Heire for't; one that can
Juſtly inherit nothing but the Gallows.
Wheres Brookalls ſon? He had a hopefull one;
And, at ſixteen, a Student here ith' Temple.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Alaſſe his Fathers fall has ruined him.
sp.l: Meere want of maint'nance forc'd him to ſervice;
In which hee's lately travell'd into France.

lg.l: Go backe to the Recorders: Fetch the War|rant,
Ile ſearch the City and the Suburbs for her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: But Vermine has a daughter may prove good,

lg.l: A good one like enough: Ile lay a wager
Hee's poching 'mong the trees here, for a Broker;
To match his daughter to a landed husband.
This is their walk.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Let's try if we can fit him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou'lt nere indure his breath, it ſtinkes of brimſtone.

lg.l: Ile take the wind of him: You are well met, Sir.
They ſay you have a daughter you would match, Sir.
It may be I have; it may be not; How then?
What's that to you?
Pray be not angry Sir.
The worſt of us has land, and may deſerve her.
Pray let me ask you firſt, if you be not
The knaves conſederates that ſtole her from me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſtolne from you Sir? In troth I am glad on't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Tis the firſt newes we heard on't.

lg.l: Though J aſſure you
We heard none ill to day: But very good,
As that of the New Ordinary.—
Then the good ſucceſſe
This Gentleman had lately with a wife—
And laſtly, this you tell us; which, but that
It comes from your own mouth, were e'en too good
For our belief, me-thinks.
Pray, is it true Sir?
That your daughter's gone, loſt, or ſtolne, as you ſay?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: May we report it after you, good Sir?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What are you? I would know.

lg.l: Gentlemen, Sir,
That cannot but rejoyce at your affliction.
And therefore blameleſſe, that deſire to hear it.
Cannot this place▪ where Law is chiefly ſtudied,
Relieve me with ſo much, as may revenge
Me on theſe ſcorners? How my Slave ſtayes too!
Yet I may find a time.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Look, look, what thing is this?—

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Trebaſco, Skip-kennel.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: It ſpeaks, me-thinks.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yes, and its ſhadow anſwers it in Corniſh▪

lg.l: I know him; 'tis the wi●e Weſtern Knight, that ſhould
Have married Vermines daughter.
Skipkennell, you ſhall turn Footman, now, Skipkennell.
I'le nere keep horſe more—

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You muſt be Footman then your ſelf Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No nor Mare neither.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You need not Sir, now you be determined to marry, and live here i'the City altogether. And truly, Sir, ſhe could never ha' dyed better, nor been taken from you (as they ſay) in a better time▪ ſo neere her journeys end.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: His Mare's dead it ſeems.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
Was it well done of her, doſt thinke, to die
to day upon the way, when ſhe had been i'my purſe to morrow in Smithfield: Poor fool, I think ſhe dyed for grief I would ha' ſold her.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: 'Twas unlucky to refuſe Reynold Pengutlings money for her.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Would I had taken't now: and ſhe had not dyed mine own, 'twould nere have griev'd me.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Pray hear it Sir, as they ſay—We are all mor|tall you know, and her time was come, we muſt think.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And't had not been the firſt loſſe that ere I had in my life, I could ha' born it.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: And grace og (as they ſay) it ſhall not be the laſt.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I would thou couldſt aſcertain me that; but miſchiefes are taild to one another, and I muſt grieve as well for the what's to come, as the departed.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: We will have a bout with him: Who is depar|ted, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: My Mare, my Mare Sir: 'Twas the prettieſt Tit—But ſhe is gone—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: How, is ſhe gone Sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You will not talk to 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: How is ſhe gone, I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Sir, as it were, becauſe ſhe could goe no fur|ther.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good angry man give us leave to talk with thy Maſter.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Good Sir a little more of your Mare.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: I would you had her all to do you good Sir: ſhe lies but a quarter of a mile beyond Brainford.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Did you leave skin and ſhooes, and all behind Sir?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Shoes all behind▪ I thought how wiſe you were: Come away Maſter▪ No, while ſhe liv'd, ſhe never wore but two behind Si●.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Gramercy honeſt fellow, thou haſt wit in thy anger.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Sirrah, anſwer not the Gentleman ſo ſnap|piſhly.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: How can I chooſe, when they do nothing but make a foole of your Worſhip before your Worſhips face, and your Worſhip perceives it not.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good Sir, fall from your man to your beaſt a|gaine.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: There againe, another main mock: He would have him fall from a man to a beaſt.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Give me the ſhoon; let 'em go I ſay, I will have 'em.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Pray take 'em then, hee'l ne're be wiſer.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Theſe were her ſhoon Gentlemen, I'le keep 'em for her ſake, that little Tit, my little poor Gonhel|ly, that would have carried me on this little iron from Penſans to S. Columb on a day. And that's a way would try a ſtumbler you'l ſay, if you know it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, I know you Sir Amphilus, and have fool'd enough with you. Adieu; my buſineſſe calls me. Gentlemen, will you meet me to night at the Ordinary▪—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yes, and perhaps, be there before you too. Come Ambroſe—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Od Gentlemen, me-thinks

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Why did you talk with 'em? What had you to make with 'em?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: True, wee have other matters to think on: Your firſt courſe Trebaſco, after we come to our lodg|ing, ſhall be to Turnbull-ſtreet, to the Cobler▪

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Your Dog-tutor.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, and ſee how my whelp proves, I put to him laſt Term.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And know of him what Gameſters came to the Ponds now adayes, and what good dogs.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And ask him—Doſt thou heare? If he ha' not done away his own dog yet, Blackswan with the white foot? If I can but purchaſe him, and my own whelp prove right, I will be Duke of the Ducking-pond.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Never miſdoubt, your whelp's right I warrant you; for why, he could lap before he could well go: And at ten weeks old he could piſſe under leg.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: He was a fine forward Puppy, true enough: But and that be a ſigne of ſhort life, and he ſhould peak away after my Mare now—Here, prethee take her ſhoon againe: What ſhould I keep 'em for? They put me too much in mind of mortality, do 'em away, make money of 'em, and Ile convert it into a Dog-Collar—

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: Ile try the Market with 'em.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: the frumping Jacks are gone.—

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: See my Aldermanicall Father-in-Law! How d'yee do Sir? I am come. I keep my day you ſee before I am a Cittiner among you. How does my beſt belov'd I pray, your daughter? You do not ſpeak me-thinks.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ask you for my daughter? Let me aske you firſt what was your plot to put me in this fright, to make me trudge to your Inn, whilſt knave your man here—Is not this he?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I doubt Sir he was taller.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p:
Having firſt left a bag of Trumpery with me,
ſtones, and old iron, ſteals away the baggage.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: This is abhomination! What Inn? and what old iron? I came at no Inne to day, nor touch old I|ron, but that with ſorrow enough, my poore Mares ſhoes, she left me at her ſad deceaſe to Brainford. I had rather ha' loſt the beſt part of five Mark J wuſſe: From whence I came by water, landed here at the Temple, to leave a Letter to a kinſmans chamber, now right as ſure as can be. Say Trebaſco.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: He tells you true.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: But is your daughter gone?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Gone, gone.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: All ill go with her: Did not I ſay I ſhould hear of more miſchief, and that one was ever tail'd to another?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: You ſaid ſo indeed: but if ſhe had been tail'd to your Mare, I ſhould have ſeen her ſure, when I ſtript her.

lg.l: This is the day of my affliction,
This day Ile croſſe out of my Almanack
For ever having any thing to do on't.
Why then, you will not ſeeke her out to day
Although me-thinks the day might ſerve as well
To find her, as to loſe her, if luck ſerve.
What elſe did you intend Sir by the warrant?
Beſt loſe no time Sir.
No, no, wee'l go.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Firſt take my execration with thee, Monſter.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Hell vomits all her malice this day on me.

lg.l: Hell ſends by mee this commendation to thee,
That thou haſt there a moſt deſerved Poſſeſſion,
That gapes to entertain thee.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who's this, a Conjure● that knowes hell ſo?

lg.l: No, but a certain Spirit, that my Maſter
Conjur'd out of his Land.
If you can conjure,
Here's money to be got Sir, but to tell us
What may be now betid of this mans daughter?
Himſelf, and his Poſterity muſt all
Sink unavoydably to hell.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: You are moſt deeply read! May not a Son-in-Law—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why talk you to that Rayler?

lg.l: Pray Sir, may not
A Son-in-Law eſcape in your opinion?
No Sir: it was by Law he made the purchaſe.
And by his Son-in-Law, or out-law'd, down he muſt:
If he ſet ventrous foot, as his Inheritor,
Upon the mould, was got by his oppreſſion.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pretty mad reaſon me-thinks; where's that Land?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sirrah, Ile tame thy tongue▪

lg.l: No, wretch, thou canſt not,
Nor fly out of the reach of my fell curſes,
That freedome (being all that thou haſt left me)
Thou canſt not rob me of.
I ſhall find meanes
Then to confine it, and your ſelf in Bed lame:
Thou canſt not be ſo juſt ſure, to exchange
Thine own inheritance for mine.
Have you made
A purchaſe there too, Father-Law that ſhould be?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How am I tortur'd! I will fly this place.

div.stage: Enter Phillis, a box in her hand.

lg.l: Nay prethee ſtay a little, good old man,
Give ſomething to my box.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Out on thee Baggage.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A little ſomething, prethee; but a teſter.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Out, out.

lg.l: Thou look'ſt like a good Penny-father,
A little of thy money would ſo thrive here,
'Twould grow, by that I were ready for a husband,
Up to a pretty portion. Pray thee now—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What canſt thou be?

lg.l: Inſooth a Gentlewoman, but a By-blow,
My Father is a Knight, but muſt be nameleſſe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Can Knights get Beggars?

lg.l: Why not? when ſuch as thou get Knights.
Nay, prethee, prethee now gi' me a teſter.
I ne're ask leſſe: My mother's a poore Gentlewoman,
And has no meanes, but what comes through my fingers.
And this is all my work: Come, wring it out.
Oh how I love a hard-bound Money-maſter,
Whoſe count'nance ſhewes how loath hee is to part with't!
It comes ſo ſweetly from him, when it comes:
Nay, when? I pray thee when? Piſh, make an end.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: It is the prettieſt merry Beggar.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Huſwife Ile ha' you whipt.

lg.l: I, when I beg i'th' ſtreets.
I have allowance here▪ as well as any
Brokers, Projectors, Common Bail, or Bankrupts,
Pandars; and Cheaters of all ſorts, that mix here
Mongſt men of honor, worſhip, lands and money.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O rare Beggar-wench!

div.stage: Lawyers and others paſſe over the Stage as conferring by two and two.

lg.l: I come not hither to in|trap or cozen.
My work lies plain before me as my way.
With, will you give me? Praythee, hard old man.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Away, away.

lg.l: What though thou com'ſt to deal
For this mans Land, or ſell anothers right,
Or els to match thy daughter, if thou haſt one
To this young Gentleman—Thou wilt give mee ſomething.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: The Devill haunts me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Shee makes a youth of me.

lg.l: Yet I prethee make not
Thy money ſuch an Idoll, as to think
Thou ſhalt diſhonor't, or impaire this bargain,
That match, or whatſoever thou haſt in traffick,
By parting with a ſilly ſilver ſixpence.
Shalt not i'fecks la, ſhalt not; Ile ſtrike luck to it,
Thy match ſhall thrive the better. Look, I have got
Here, four and ſixpence, Prethee make it a Crowne,
Twill nere be miſt in thy dear daughters Dowry,
If (as I ſaid) thou haſt one.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Helliſh baggage!

lg.l: Hee'l gi't me by and by. I prethee find
Thy money out the while. Come out with it man:
Pull her away,
I fly thee, as I would the Devill that ſent thee:

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Yes, let's away, tis time, ſhe begs of mee now.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Devill is not ſurer to o're-take thee.—

lg.l: Good child I thanke thee: Thou haſt ſome|what eas'd
My penſive heart by his vexation:
She ſpake as Divination had inſpit'd her
With knowledge of my wrongs; and his oppreſſion,
To take my part: Take thou a bleſſing for't
Who ere thou art, whilſt I recalculate
The miſeries of a diſtreſſed man,
Caſt out of all. Unhappy chance of Law!
More falſe and mercileſſe then Dice or Strumpets;
That haſt into thy Hydra-throated mawe
Gulp'd up my lives ſupportance; left me nothing;
Not means for one dayes ſuſtenance, for breath
To cry thy cruelty before my death.
That Law, once called ſacred, and ordain'd
For ſafety and reliefe to innocence,
Should live to be accurs'd in her ſucceſſion,
And now be ſtil'd Supportreſſe of oppreſſion;
Ruine of Families, paſt the bloody rage
Of Rape or Murder: All the crying ſins
Negotiating for Hell in her wild practiſe.

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: A man I hope for my purpoſe, and ſave me a going to the Church for one: Will you make an Oath Sir?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: An Oath? for what?

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: For two ſhillings; and it▪ be half a Crowne, my Client ſhall not ſtand w'ye; the Judge is at leiſure, and the other of our Bail is there already. Come, go along.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: I gueſſe you ſome Attorney: Do you know me?

sp.speaker: At.
sp.p: No, nor any man we imploy in theſe caſes.

lg.l: He takes me for a common Bail; a Knight o'th Poſt,
Thou art a villaine, and crop-ear'd I doubt not:
What, dar'ſt thou ſay, thou ſeeſt upon me, that—
I cry you mercy: I muſt up (I ſee)
To the old Synagogue, there I ſhall be fitted—
Can I appear ſo wretched? or can grief
So ſoile the face of poverty, which is vertue,
To make it ſeem that Monſter Perjury?
Rather let ſorrow end me all at once,
Then vertue be miſconſtrued in my looks,
Which I will hide from ſuch inter|pretation.
Alas hee's ſore afflicted, and my newes,
I fear, will ſtrike him dead; yet I muſt ſpeak.
Sir, give not miſery that advantage on you,
To make your ſelf the leſſe, by ſhrinking under
The buffe●ings of fortune.
I deſir'd you
To ſeek my ſon. Ha' you found him at his Chamber?
Or has not want of fatherly ſupplies
(VVhich heaven knowes I am robb'd of) thruſt him out
Of Commons, to the Common VVorld for ſuccour?
Where is he, have you found him?
No, not him.
But I have found what may be comfort to you,
If you receive it like a man of courage.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Hee's dead then, farewell my tender boy▪

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, hee's not dead.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Phew—

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, heare me.

lg.l: You'll tell me, man nere dies; But changeth Life,
And happily for a better. He is happieſt
That goes the right way ſooneſt: Nature ſent us
All naked hither; and all the Goods we had
We onely took on Credit with the World.
And that the beſt of men are but meer borrowers:
Though ſome take longer day. Sir, J know all
Your Arguments of Conſolation—

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.p: Indeed he is not dead; but lives—

lg.l: In Heaven.
J am the ſurer on't; for that he liv'd
Not to learn Law enough, to—huſh. No more.

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.p: Subſtantially he lives in fleſh, as we do▪

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Speak that again.

lg.l: A Gentleman of the next Chamber told me ſo.
Onely, ſir, this; if you can brook his abſence
Without feare, or miſtruſt; then he is well.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: How thou playeſt with me!

sp.speaker: Fren.
sp.p: He's gone to travell, ſir. Here comes the Gen|tleman.

lg.l: J am ſure he does not know me. If he could,
J were as ſure this Charity would be rejected.
So much J know his Spirit. Is your name Brookeall, ſir?

sp.speaker: Brook.
sp.p: My loſſes, wrongs, and ſorrowes, ſpeak my name.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You had a Son late of this houſe.

lg.l: And do not you infer by that he▪s dead?
Good, do not mock me, ſir.
If this be gold,
He lives and ſent it to you; forty peeces?
Pray, ſir, from whence, or where might he atchieve
So great a Sum? Not in this World, J feare.
A handſome poſſibility he had once,
Could J ha' kept it for him.
He's in a way,
Now to a hopefull fortune. A Noble Gentleman,
Late gone to travell, ta'ne with good affection
Towards your Son, has ta'ne hin to his care:
And like a Father, not a Maſter, keeps him.
From whoſe free bounty he receiv'd this meanes.
Do you think the Boy did well to ſend it me then:
When twas intended for his Maſters honour,
To flye in Silks and Feathers? Tis not Servant like
To wave a Maſters meaning ſo.
J had a Letter too;
Though moſt unhappily miſlay'd.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: VVhat from my Boy?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: In his own hand.

lg.l: Ha!—but miſlay'd, you ſay. Ha, ha, ha,—
VVhat is the Gentleman? Or whither travell'd?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That's all J crave excuſe for.

lg.l: Keep your money.
If you can render me my Son, Ile thank you.
You ſpeak not like a Father: wanting meanes
Your ſelfe for his advancement, would you bar him
The bounty of anothers full ability?
J ſpeak more like a Father, then a Beggar:
Although no Beggar poorer. And I feare,
J am no Father: for J would not give
My Son to gain a Province, nor except
This Coyne to ſave my life: If he 〈…〉
Let me look neerer 〈…〉
He will accept the Money. Poverty
Was nere ſo coy elſe.
J cannot remember,
J ever ſaw this face: But J have ſeen
(Many yeares ſince) one, that it ſo reſemble●,
As J could ſpit defiance on't—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What mean you?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: And charge thee with the Murther of my Son

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray, ſir, collect your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Your name is Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Right, ſir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Sir Humphrey Drygrounds Son:

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Moſt true.

lg.l: Even ſo thy Father look'd, when, at like years
He was my Rivall: For young man, I tell thee
Thou hadſt a virtuous, well deſerving Mother.
He won her without loſſe of my known Friend-ſhip:
But, ſince her death, you cannot but have heard,
He ba●ely wrong'd my Siſter, and, in her,
Mee, and my Family: Whor'd her, and caſt her off,
On the appointed Marriage day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O, ſir.

lg.l: You cannot but have heard on't. Nay, it ſeems,
My Boy has charg'd thee with't, before his yeares
Could warrant his ability in Combate.
And ſo is fallen; Or thou, not daring ſtand
Tryall in ſuch a cauſe, by treachery
Haſt cut him off; And com'ſt to make thy peace:
Preſuming on my Poverty, with money.
Worſe then the baſe Attornies Project this!
This is meer madneſſe. In an Act ſo foule,
As your wilde Fancy gathers this to be;
Who could eſcape the Law?
The Law; Ha, ha, ha.
Talk not to me of Law, Law's not my Friend.
Law is a Fatall to me, as your houſe.
I have enough of Law; pray ſtand you off.
Will you, ſir, furniſh me, but with a Sword;
And bring me to fit ground to end this difference?
Will you do ſo, and like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: VVhat ſhall J do for pity?—Now J have it.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Talk not to me of Law.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray heare me, ſir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Now ſir, your wil before your end. Be briefe.

lg.l: You know me for a Gentleman, though an E|nemy.
(I muſt ſpeak in his phraſe) and by that honour
A Gentleman ſhould keep ſacred, two houres hence
Ile meet you in this place—

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Pray ſtand you off—to Friendly.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: From whence wee▪ll walke—

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Silent, as nothing were—

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: As nothing were betwixt us—to ſome other Fit ground, (as you propounded) where wee'll end the difference.

lg.l: By the Sword, no otherwiſe.
No whinnelling ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee, ſir.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Go ſet thy houſe in order. Here Ile meet thee,

lg.l: I Shall repent me, ſir, that ere I yeilded,
In that faire Noble way, if you expreſſe
Your ſelfe in this regardleſſe of my honour.
J like a Whore, withall my heart, that talkes
So like an honeſt woman.
Can you expect
A Chaſt and conſtant Wife of her, Whom you
Have wrought to Lewdneſſe before Marriage?
Or may J not as well deſerve as well in bringing
A Maidenhead into your Marriage-bed,
As a polluted Body?
Here's a coyle,
For a poore bit afore-hand! Is it ſo?
'Heart, if a man beſpeak a Tavern Feaſt
For next day Dinner; and give earneſt for't
To half the value, (as my Faith and Troth
J think, is ſomewhat towards your Marriage payment
To be to morrow) Will not the Hoſteſſe give him
A Modicum o're night to ſtay his ſtomack?
Your Father comes: Jle whiſper yet more reaſon.
Now pretty Mr. Alice, you ſee the end
I had upon you: All the ſcope thereof
Tending to your contentment. Are you pleas'd?
So well, that could I but ſhake off the feare
(Which is moſt dangerous) of a Fathers curſe,
I durſt prouounce; nay, boaſt my happineſſe,
To be above my Virgin hopes, or wiſhes.
Let your feare vaniſh then: And, if this night,
The happineſs you are ambitious of,
Together with your Fathers leave and bleſſing
Crown not your Bed, let all the Infamy
Due to all perjur'd Wretches, that have wrong'd
Beauty and Chaſtity be branded here.
The faire reſpect I have, ſir, to your Nobleſſe;
For what you have already ſhown me, bars
Mine eares 'gainſt proteſtation. I dare truſt you.
As I have truſted you with my whole project,
My diſcreet Alice, further then I dare truſt
My Inſtrument your Brother; though he thinks
He underſtands it all. Yonder he is,
Profoundly Love-ſtruck too, J make no doubt.

sp.speaker: Fry.
sp.p: Fye! Can you be ſo lew'd? Is that your rea|ſon?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes; can the Pariſh Parſon give you better?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: His Pariſh Bull's as civill.

lg.l: Well no more.
Ile talke with your Father about it.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: J with your Siſter, and to better purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Now Wat, what think you of my courſe, and habit?

lg.l: As J love miſchiefe, and deſire to live by't;
It is the daintieſt courſe.—O, brave ſir Humphrey,
How I am taken with your Shape! Old Osbright,
The Father of the Swindgers; ſo much talk'd on
Could nere ha' borne it up ſo. Nor his Daughter,
That was French born indeed, could ere have clipp'd,
And Frenchified our Engliſh better, then
She counterfeits to Coxcombes that do Court her:
With her fine Fee-fees, and her Laiſſe-moys;
Her Prea-awayes; Intrat a you mak a me bluſha.
O, J am tickled with it.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: A, ha, my Lad.

lg.l: ſlid J could dote upon you. Had J been
Your Son now, how I could have honour'd you!
Though I had kept a Precept by t, I care not.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Notable Reprobate.

lg.l: The Devill ſure
Ought me a miſchiefe, when he enabled that
Old Wretch, my Father to beget me. Oh,
Tis in my bones; I ſeele it in my Youth:
I know from whence the Pocks is now deſcended.
The Gout begets it. There's no Uſurers Son,
But's born with an hereditary ſpice on't.
Had J rak'd Limbo, as J did the Compter,
I were not better fitted with a Copeſmate.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'ſlight, I could ask you bleſſing.

lg.l: And I think,
That curteſie you have ſeldome done your Father.
Nere ſince I grew to any underſtanding:
Nor (as I know) before, but whipt and held to't.
Well Wat. You ſee how far I have truſted you,
To have the ſecond hand in our great work;
Our Project here. Though you muſt ſeem my Servant,
You are like to have the better ſhare, if you agree.
Upon the Match, and make your ſelfe my Son.
How like you your new Miſtreſſe, ſir, my Daughter;
The Maidenhead here, the new Ordinary—
The Damoyſelle, or what you pleaſe to call her?
What iſt a Match Wat? Condeſcendeth ſhe?
No man ſhall be her Husband, but my ſelfe;
Who ere ſhe lies withall, before or after.
That ſhe has roundly promis'd. But ſhe balkes,
And Boggles with me in a leſſe requeſt.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: She ſhall deny thee nothing. What iſt Wat?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You may command her duty, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What is it man?

lg.l: 'Troth, ſir, but one nights knowledge
Of her aforehand. One word of your mouth,
I know would do it, ſir.
O Deviliſh Raſcall,
That can imagine this a Fathers Office▪
Patience good Wat.
But that I am afeard
My Father would be pleas'd with't, Il'd take home
My Siſter elſe, and preſently.
In Maides about your work. And heare you Franck
Diſcharge the Butchers, and the Chandlers Bills.
They wait below. The Baker and the Brewer,
I have made even with.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: And the Vintner too.

lg.l: The Bottle-man too, and Tobacco Merchant.
Do as I bid you, go. Now Wat Obſerve me:
As an ingenious Critick would obſerve
The firſt Scene of a Cemedy, for feare
He loſe the Plot.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I do obſerve you, ſir.

lg.l: I have, you know, releas'd from your thrall|dome.
Upon condition you ſhould ſteale your Siſter,
To be at my diſpoſe. You have perform'd it:

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Honeſtly, ſir.

lg.l: Yes▪ honeſtly, as you ſay.
And though it be for her own abſolute good;
Yet was your Act ſo gratefull to me, that
I promis'd you my Daughter.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Right ſir, on.

lg.l: I ſhall be briefe: you know my Fortune, VVat
Are ſunk, and you have heard, I make no doubt,
'Mongſt other of my follies, of a Child
I got on Brookealls ſiſter, on the by, Wat.
And this is ſhe, I love a baſtard naturally,
Ah thy are bouncing ſpirits: Now I love her
More then I did Sir.
You come fairely on.
But now, my poverty affords no portion.
Now, Wat, to raiſe a portion!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: J, now, now.

lg.l: Now I come to it, Wat: J tooke this houſe,
And in this habit here, turn'd pimping Hoſt,
To make the moſt of her, and find a Husband
To take her with all faults.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That's I, that's I Sir: this has muſick in't.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: You will be ſecret Wat.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No dumb Bawde like me.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Nay in a plot of villany I dare truſt thee.

lg.l: In troth you cannot thinke how much I love it;
How I am tickled with it! Good Sir, on.
This I have deſign'd to put her off
(I mean her Maiden-head) at ſuch a rate
Shall purchaſe Land.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How, good Sir Humphrey, how?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: She ſhall be rifled for.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How! Rifled Sir?

lg.l: Yes, rifled Wat; the moſt at three fair throws,
With three fair Dice, muſt win and wear her, Wat.
Youle take her with all faults?
Can you ſuſpect me?
It is the rareſt invention, if the Gameſters
Be ſtiffe and ſtrait, that ever was projected!
What is't a man?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: But twenty Pieces, boy.

lg.l: I vow too little, leſſe their number help us.
How many Gamſters have you?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: A full hundred.

lg.l: Two thouſand pound! A merry portion,
And worth as many Maiden-heads in the ſport
A man ſhall finde in ſpending it? Me-thinks
I feele my ſelf even flying with't already.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What art thou thinking, Wat?

lg.l: That here may grow
A danger Sir, the Gameſters being ſo many.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Why, there's but one muſt uſe her.

lg.l: Phew, for that
I were indifferent, if 'twere all or more
(As it is poſſible a wench might bear it)
If they come ſingle, and in civill ſort,
Allow her breathing-whiles—

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Here's a ripe Raſcall!

lg.l: But my doubt is, that ſuch a multitude
May fly into combuſtion, blow up all
The buſineſſe and our hopes.
Now your doubt
Reflects upon my Iudgement: didſt thou note
How quietly thoſe Gallants here to day
Parted with their gold?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Yes, very gallantly.

lg.l: They ſhall agree as well for the Commodity,
As I have caſt it, VVat; ſo well my boy,
That no diſtaſte ſhall be or ta'ne, or given,
Anon youle ſee.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: She knows not on't you ſay,

lg.l: Nor ſhall ſhe VVat, till at the puſh I charge her
To be obedient in the undertaking.
And that's a ſweet obedience: I could kneel
Before my wretched Sire in ſuch commands.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Anon Ile make't all plain to you. How now Frank?

lg.l: There are two Gentlemen in the next room,
That by all meanes would ſpeake with you: I have had
The fouleſt coyle with one of 'em, that perſwades
Himſelfe you keep a Bawdy-houſe, by ſomewhat
He gather'd Eveſdropping, by your diſcourſe here,
While t'other held me talking; who is civill,
And loves me with a modeſt fair affection.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Where is his ſiſter, Alice?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Unſeen I wrrrant you.

lg.l: Then let them enter. Whip into your diſguiſe Wat— Exit Fran.
And be at call.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: Preſto, Anon, anon Sir.

lg.l: Did they Eaveſdrop me? I will
Eaveſdrop too.—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Did not I tell thee't was a Bawdy-houſe?

lg.l: I cannot think ſo yet: there is ſome other
Trick in it; the Maid you ſee is very modeſt.
That is the trick on it man, ſhe muſt ſeem ſo.
Her Father deals for her.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Fye! Can there be ſuch Fathers?

lg.l: Yes, and ſuch Mothers too: The Towne's too full of 'em.
Come, ſhee's a Jugling whore I warrant thee,
For all her Fee-fees, and her Laiſſe-moys.
Pox of her counterfeit Gibbriſh Ile make her ſpeak
In plainer Engliſh, ere I ha' done with her.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I have enough. You are welcome Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: He looks like ſuch a Blade. Are you the Maſter here Sir?

lg.l: I am the man that's much rejoyc'd to ſee
Such ſparkling Spirits underneath this Roofe,
Where all you finde is yours. Sirrah Varlet.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Each ſyllable he ſpeaks bewrays him.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Varlet I ſay.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Here Sir.

lg.l: Give me the Complement. Gallants,
Wilt pleaſe you taſte your welcome in a Cup,
The ſpirit of whoſe never dying Liquor,
Speaks ore the brim in this high Language to you.
Full ſix and thirty times hath Luna wan'd
The ſtrength ſhe got in ſix and thirty growths
From Phoebus vertuous beames, into this Juyce,
To make it Nectar for Phoebean wits.
Tis this inſpires their braines with fire Divine,
By which to write high ſtraines; and herein lurks,
The gift, One has to bounce up his own works.
Your meaning is good Sack, and three years old.
To put you by your Beverage and your Bombaſt,
I will nor drinke, nor talke of other thing,
But the choice thing of things, your Daughter Sir.
Thou ſhalt not wooe my Daughter, nor no man for thy ſake, Sing.
Unlaſſe thou come untill her by her Daddy nak'd.
Her Mammy's gone to Heaven Sir. And I pray,
Let Fathers poor breed Daughters as they may.
Your care, no doubt, is great what will it hold?
The Rifling Sir, I meane. Is your number full?
May not a man put in Sir for a chance?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir?

lg.l: May not we
Come in adventurers? Here are twenty peeces.
I finde you have overheard me. Call my Daugh|ter. Exit Wat.
Now Ile diſcloſe a ſecret to you. But Gentlemen,
As you love wit and mirth, cenſure me mildly.
I am a Gentleman decayd in Fortune.
And canſt thou be ſo baſe to ſell thy Childe
To Luſt and Impudence?
Be not too raſh.
My Child's as deare in my reſpect, as you
Were ever to your Father.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Devill thou lyeſt—

lg.l: Nay, hold, good Ambroſe; you een now were angry
With me, that did oppoſe your faire Conſtruction
Of this good Gentleman and his vertuous Daughter.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: My ignorance wrong'd us both.

lg.l: Good modeſt Ambroſe,
What do you thinke of this diſcovery?
You had diſcover'd more, if his impatience
Had not prevented me: But now I am dumb to you
In all, but this. If youle be pleas'd to ſup here,
I ſhall afford you welcome. I have buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What can we make of this?

lg.l: I know what to do.
If City Juſtice, grave Authority
Protect it not, Ile ſurely ſpoyle the ſport.
Canſt thou be ſo malicious, that, but now
Didſt love this Wench ſo dearly, as to run her
Into the hazard of Correction?

Stay: Here ſhe comes, and the Pimp whiskin with her.
Enter Wat. Fran.
Do thou take him in hand. Ile handle her.
Now Madam, twenty pound a man! Nay do not
Coy it too much? Your provident Father left us,
To make our ſelves more known to you; as your price
Is known to us already: Look upon us.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Pre ye Sir, have you been ever in France?

lg.l: In France? No ſurely, nor in Doctors hands
Since I was Plac●et high. Why ask you Lady?
For, if you could ſpeak Franſh, I could the better
Find what you ſay. I can no underſtand
What tis you mean by price. What is that Price,
If it be no Welch Gentleman?
I meane
The price of three throws for your Maydenhead,
Tis twenty peeces. If I win it (Hearke you)
What will you give me out of your groſſe ſum
To take it neatly off; and like an Operator,
Put you to no paine?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Parle Françoy Monſieur, Je vou prie.

lg.l: Thou art a handſome Hyppocrite: And this
Cunning becomes thee well. Ile kiſſe thee for't.
Fee fee Monſieur. O fee! tis no good faſhion,
For the young Man and Mayd to no ting but kiſſe!
Tis not ſo good indeed; nothing but kiſſe.
A little of tone with tother will doe well.
Fee fee, you no underſtand. That Gentleman,
Speaks he no Fransh?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Yes yes. He ſpeaks no French.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: He Monſieur vou mocque de Moy.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Owie par ma foy.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Ha Monſieur vou parle françoy. Je ſu●' bien aiſie.

lg.l: Eaſie! Yes yes, I thinke you would be eaſie
To one that knew but how to manage you,
For all the boaſt of your Virginity.
Excuſe me Sir, I can no underſtand.
Me thinks you ſhould. Come prithee leave this fooling,
I know you can good Engliſh, if you liſt.
Indeed I can. But, in my beſt, and all
I cannot underſtand you Sir, nor frame
An anſwer to your rudeneſſe. When you know me
Better, youle ſpeak in better phraſe, and then
Tis like you may finde better language from me:
Till when, pray give me leave to leave you Sir.
Nay heark you Lady, heark you (ſtill more my|ſticall!)
Nay ſince you can ſpeak Engliſh, I muſt talke w'ye.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: So youle be civill.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Civill I ſwear, and private.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: Does ſhee not know on't, ſayſt thou?

lg.l: No Sir, no:
Not the leaſt inckling of it: The old man
Carryes it ſo diſcreetly.
Bleſſe me Heaven?
Diſcreetly ſayſt thou. To betray his Childe,
To ſale of her Virginity.
Yes, diſcreetly.
She dreames of no ſuch buſineſſe; ſuch intent:
No more then the Cud-chewing Heifer knowes
The Butcher, that muſt knock her down i faith.
O, twill be bravely carried! I my ſelfe
Knew nothing till this houre: though I ſaw
Money put in his hand by divers Gallants:
Men of great place and worſhip; which I gather
Are to be of the Riflers.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Prithee who?

lg.l: All muſt be nameleſſe. There are Lords among 'em.
And ſome of civill Coat, that love to draw
New ſtakes at the old Game, as well as they;
Truckle-breech'd Juſtices, and buſtling Lawyers,
That thruſt in with their Motions; Muffled Citizens;
Old Money-Maſters ſome, that ſeek the Purchace:
And Merchant Venturers that bid for the
Forreine Commodity, as faire, as any.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch an outrage! Heark thee fellow—

lg.l: Sir, I have heard you with that patience
(And with no better) as the troubled Pilot
Endures a Tempeſt, or contrary winds:
Who, finding neretheleſſe his Tackling ſure,
His Veſſell tight, and Sea-room round about him,
Playes with the waves, and vies his confidence
Above the blaſts of Fortune, till he winns
His way, through all her threatnings, to his Port.
You may apply this.
And you may be plainer.
Is there not ſuch a project for your Mayden head?
It deſerves no anſwer.
But to be rid of you, together with
The Devill, that inflam'd you to that queſtion;
Know, that knew I of ſuch a plot or project;
Or, that I had a Father (as injuriouſly
You have ſuggeſted) could be ſo inhumane,
To proſtitute my ſpotleſſe Virgine honour
To Luſt for Salary, I would as ſure prevent it,
As there is force in poyſon, Cord, or Steel,
At price of both our lives. Sir, I have ſay—
This Wench amazes me. Could I beleeve now
There could be truth in Woman, I could love her.
Well, Ile make one: Meet me there two houres hence,
And fetch my twenty Peices.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I will not faile you. In the Temple Walkes—

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Where, if I fit you not—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Nam! What diſcovery?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: A villany enough to blow the houſe up.

lg.l: And I have found (I thinke) a vertue, that
Might ſave a City: But let's hence. We may
Conferr our notes together by the way.

div.head: Scene II.
div.stage: Bumpſey, Magdalen, Jane, all in brave Cloaths.

lg.l: NAy, nay, I know he is flown out, and I
Am prettily provided for like flight:
And if I do not pitch as high, and ſouſe
As deep, as he, while there is Game to fly at—
Five hundred Peices he took out you ſay?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And ſayd he would venter't at the Ordinary.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Thats hee, thats he! Why this is excellent.

lg.l: This was your folly Bump. He was content
To have walk'd moneyleſſe you ſaw, but you
Would force him. At a word you did la' Bump.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: I force him, ha?

lg.l: I, at a word, you put it in his head,
And put the Sword into the Madmans hand,
As one would ſay.
Good Mrs. At-a-word.
Let not your fine French Frippery, which I bought,
Turn'd oth' Taylors hands (as one would ſay)
Huffle you up to Soveraignty: Nor your Coach,
Which I have but beſpoak, whirle you away,
Before tis finiſh'd) from obedience,
Good lack fine Gentleman, that weares the Purchaſe
Of a Pawn'd forfeiture. Muſt I not ſpeak trow?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Excellent Magdalen!

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Sir, J will ſpeak; and be allow'd to ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: And ſpeak allow'd too; will you Magdalen?

lg.l: J, at a word; Since you have put me to't,
J will uphold the Fashion; Learn, and practiſe
Behaviour and carriage above my'parrell.
J at a word, J will la, that J will.
This is moſt excellent! My old Beaſt is
Infected with the Faſhions; Faſhion-ſick!
Pray Ma-dame take your courſe, uphold your Faſhion:
And learn and practiſe Carriage to your Cloaths:
I will maintain my humour, though all ſplit by't.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Mr. Ʋermine deſires to ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: I faith I will Ma-dame.—

lg.l: My Husband, Mother,
Reports of a rare Creature come to Towne,
Of a French breed; a Damoyſell, that profeſſeth
The teaching of Court-carriage and behaviour:
The rar'ſt he ſaies—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Can ſhe teach the elder ſort?

lg.l: All ages from ſix yeares to ſixty ſix.
Unleſſe they be indocible he ſaies.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Indocible! What's that?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Stiff i'the hammes, I think.

lg.l: Nay, then wee'll to her.
I can yet bowe my Haunches; come and go
With them, as nimbly as the barren Doe.
My Gimboles don't complain for want of Oyle yet.
Wee'll have this Madame; and we will be Madames
Ourſelves, or it ſhall coſt us each a Crown
A month the teaching. In a Month we may,
Practiſing but one houre in a day,
Be Madames, may we not?
Yes, if we give our mindes to't; and but ſteale
Fit times to practiſe.
Wee'll find Lecture times:
Or bau●k St. Antlius for't the while. But mum.
Do you wonder at my bravery? Look you here:
This is my Wife; and this my Daughter, ſir.
You have loſt yours, you ſay: Perhaps for want
Of Hu●ty-●uſties, and of Gorgets gay.
Ha! iſt not ſo?
The World's turn'd prodigall.
You do not well to mock me, when I come
For comfort and adviſe.
Shall I be plain w'ye;
My beſt adviſe is, ſince your Daughters gone,
To turn your Son after her. He lies not in
For much above a hundred pound. Pay it,
And let him take his courſe: If he be not
Got looſe already. Then (obſerve my Counſell)
Spend you the reſt of your Eſtate your ſelfe;
And ſave your Heires the ſin. It is the courſe
I have in hand, and mean to follow it.
You like it not (it ſeems) but thus it is,
VVhen men adviſe for nothing. Had your Lawyer
Now for his fee, given Counſell, might have damn'd you:
You would have thought it worth your Gold, and follow'd it.
VVill you go with me to an Ordinary?
Venter five hundred or a thouſand Peeces,
To begin a new VVorld with.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Mrs. Bumpſey, I take it you are she.

lg.l: An old Ape has an old eye.
He knowes me through all my cuts and ſlashes.
How long I pray, has my good friend your Hus|band
Been thus diſtracted?
But when I am perfect
In the quaint Courtly carriages, that belong
Unto this habit: in which, I confeſſe,
I am yet but raw; how will you know me then?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: She is as mad as he.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: How Lady-like she talkes!

lg.l: Or, now my black Bag's on, I hold a penny
You do not know me. Bogh-who am I now?
Moſt unrecoverably mad! young Gentlewo|man:
Nay, I intreat your favour for an anſwer?
As you can pity a wrong'd mans diſtreſſe.
Give me what light you can of my loſt Daughter.
You have been inward alwaies, and partook
The neareſt of her Counſels. Tell me fairely
I do beſeech you in this gentle way.
Though I profeſſe I have a ſtrong preſumption
Againſt your Husband, and his young Aſſociates
I met to day; and bore their mocks and taunts:
On which I have good ground for a ſtrickt courſe
To force 'em to examination.
Yet I intreat you ſee.
The VVorld is turn'd
Quite upſide downe: Elſe I should wonder
How you could make requeſts, that have got all
You have (too much) by Rapine and Oppreſſion.

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Do you upbraid me?

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: What's the matter Jane?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The Fox here learns to ſing.

lg.l: Ile fox him out oth' hole if he ſing here.
Will no Prey ſerve you but new married wives, Fox?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Why do you abuſe me thus?

lg.l: I heard you, ſir, with too much patience,
Abuſe my Husband with your foule Suſpition.
Who is as cleer, I know, from wronging you,
As your own Son.
Your mocks are monſtrous.
Were not he faſt enough, I would reſolve
No other friend had robb'd me.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Is your ſon a friend? At a word, hee's like you.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: J pray, if my man aske for mee, ſend him to me, by your Maſters leave. By your leave Sir, I made bold to follow a Father-in-Law of mine that ſhould have been, into your houſe here, with much ado to find it. Any good newes Sir yet? Ha' you heard of her? J cry theſe Ladies mercy; though you may take me for a Clowne, J muſt not forget I am a Knight, and give you the curteſie of my lips—

lg.l: In the name of Peaſantry, what Knight art thou,
If not the Knight of the Plough-ſhare?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: A fine ſpoken, and a well-bred man, at a word: He call'd us Ladies. To ſee what Apparell can do! How long might I have trudg'd about in my old coats before J had been a Lady? And then hee would do us the curteſie to kiſſe us: Sure, ſure, as curteſie makes a Knight, ſo cloaths makes a Lady.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: It ſeems ſhe's loſt then. All ill go with her.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: What old youth can this be?

lg.l: Your warrant, perhaps, may find her though.
And J tell you what.
J ha' ſent my man to lay the Ducking Ponds for her.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Do you think ſhe would drown her ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Who knowes what toy might take her? Is ſhe not a woman, as other fleſh and blood is? I had another occaſion to one that belongs to the Ponds. I tell you as a Friend, I had not ●ent els: Come Father|in-Law that ſhould have been; hang ſor|row. You have had but one Loſſe to day. I have had two. Ile gi't you in Rhime.

lg.l: My Mare and my Mistreſſe I lost on a day,
T'one of 'em dyed, and t'other ran away.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You are acquainted among the Poets it ſeems, ſir?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Truly but one that's a Gamſter amongſt us at the ducking Pond; a Cobler, but the neateſt Fellow at Poetry, that ever was handicrafts-man; & no Schol|ler, to enable him by learning, to borrow of the An|cients: Yet he is a Tranſlator too. And he makes the ſweeteſt Poſies for Privie-houſes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: What a youth's this for a Knight!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ile tell yee Ladies—O Trebaſco. Good newes at laſt I hope.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: J can never finde you any where, but jeer'd and laugh'd at, and are fool'd, (as I have often told you) to your Worſhips face, and your Worſhip perceives it not.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p:
To the point, man. How does my Whelp? He
is grown a tall Dog by this J hope: reſolve me quickly.

sp.speaker: Tre▪
sp.p: Why, to put you out of your pain; your Whelp's grown a tall Dog.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Good

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You ſaid you would tell us, ſir: What will you tell us?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: And a handſome Dog.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Good again.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What a Dog-trick's is this?

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: And h'as learnt, beſides the main Game, all the rare tricks and qualities his Tutor could teach.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Will you not tell us, ſir, about your Poet?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Hang him, my Dogs worth 'em all, in ready money.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I pray, ſir.

lg.l: I will not give his eares for the ſwolnſt head|full of wit among 'em.
Are not his Eares finely curl'd Trebaſco? Like his Dam Flapſes.

sp.speaker: Tres
sp.p: Yes, and his Coat all over, ſir, they told me.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Told thee! Didſt thou not ſee him? My heart miſgives me.

lg.l: See him? No indeed, ſir; but J pray beare it as well as you may:
And ſet not your heart too much upon tranſportable things.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: The Dog is gone, ſir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How!

lg.l: Stolne from Schoole, ſir; and ſold to a great Monſieur,
And Shipt away foure daies ago.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O my heart will break:

sp.speaker: J. a
sp.p: Do not faint Knight; Cheare up your heart with your Muſe.

lg.l: My veine is yet too dul; But I will offer at it.
Three Loſſes I have had; gone, paſt all help
My Mare, my Miſtreſſe, And (which grieves me moſt of all) my whelp.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: That line is long enough to reach him.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I would it were elſe.—o—

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Od's pity. Look you, ſir, your Son-in-Law, that ſhould ha' been, is in much paſſion too. But you'll be rul'd by me, you ſay. And if J lead you not to comfort, never truſt Neighbours counſell while you live. Is not this plain enough? My own caſe at this time is as dangerous as yours.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: That's all that comforts me.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Neighbourly ſaid. I thank you. Come, Sir, will you joyn with your Father-in-Law that ſhould ha' been, and me in a Cup of VVine to order a deſigne.

sp.speaker: Tre.
sp.p: There's a reckoning towards.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: It ſhall coſt you nothing.

lg.l: To the next Tavern then. Ladies adieu.
To part with ſuch as you to ſome are croſſes.
Yet Ile not put you down among my Loſſes.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Daughter while they are gone, let us fall on our project.

sp.speaker: Ja:
sp.p: For Courtly carriage and behaviour.

lg.l: J long to ſee this French young ſchoolmiſtreſs.
The Damaſin do you call her?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The Damoiſelle, Ile wait on you.—

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: A Rabble of rude Fellowes pulling in Wat af|ter them, Valentine, Oliver, Ambroſe, Phillis.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: YOU Rogues, Slaves, Villaines, will you murther me?

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: To the Pump with him: To the Pump, to the Pump.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prithee beat off the Curs.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: No, to the Thames, the Thames.

lg.l: Why do you uſe the man ſo? Is he not a Chriſtian
Or is he not Chriſten'd enough think you, that you would dip him?
Pray Gentlemen forbeare: It is thought fit,
Upon requeſt made by a Noble Friend,
Favouring his Perſon, not his quality;
That for this time the Pandar be diſmis'd.
So all depart in peace.
Away, away, lets go then.
1. A Noble Friend! Pox of his Noble Friendſhip.
He has ſpoyl'd our ſport. O! how we would a ſous'd him?
Now, Mr. Hackney-man, if you have ſo much grace▪
Render due thanks.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: J thank you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank you for him too.

lg.l: On both your Knees; unleſs you hold it better
To kneele yet to the Pump: which you had done,
My moſt officious Pimp, had not his pity
Prevayl'd againſt our Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: So, ariſe; enough, enough.

lg.l: Troth tis a ſhame he ſhould get off ſo eaſily;
Let him be yet but duck'd, or ſhew'd the way
Over the Garden Wall into the Thames.
Good Ambroſe, be not ſo ſevere; who knowes
What need we may of him? We are all
Fleſh and blood Ambroſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Thou art a Wag I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Are not you married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Maſs, twas ſo late, I had almoſt forgotten it.
