lg.l: No, tis ſo late you ha' not yet forgot
Some Office he has done you in his way.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Didſt ever pimp for him? Proteſt by what thou fea●'ſt moſt.

sp.speaker: VVat.
sp.p: No, as I hope to eſcape this Gentlemans fury.

lg.l: Go, get the hence, inſufferable Villaine.
I could een kick thee into twenty peeces, He kicks Wat.
And ſend thee to thy Maſter, for my ſtake
Soon, at his Rifling.
Think whilſt thou liv'ſt what tis to be a Pandar.—
A Pandar,—Pandar—there's for your remembrance.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: This touch, & I have done—▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Away

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Pray let him go, Ile ſchoole him for it.

lg.l: This may work good upon the Raſcall, if he
Have but humanity, although no grace.
We have diſcovered the great Rifling Val.
We know the Jewell now; the rich Comodity.
And think you have done wondrous wiſely; do you not?
To ſneak before me thither. I know all
You have diſcover'd; and how far you are
Miſtaken in the old man and his Daughter.
All shall be plaine to you ſoon. Walk off a little.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: We'll leave you till anon we meet at the Ordina|ry.

lg.l: I proteſt, Gentlemen, I have not drown'd ſorrow
With ſo much merry▪go-down, theſe three halfe years.
As with your part of three halfe pintes of Sack.
We had no more amongſt us.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How much was that a peece think you?

lg.l: It was enough to ſhew his Prodigality.
In over-waſtfull Coſt. You were not wont
To be a Boordſend-King; a pay-all in a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: But now I love to do theſe things.

lg.l: Now if you could be drawn to the ducking-Pond,
To joyn your Groat ſometimes with me; or two-pence▪
There were a Recreation indeed:
That Peerleſſe Princely ſport, that undoes no man:
Though cheating there; and rooking be as free
As there is ſquare play at the Ordinaries.
Well the point is: My ſwaggering Son-in-Law,
Appointed to be here among the Trees.
My Daughter told me ſo. Walk here-about.
If he can give light of your light, hee'd chide.
Well try what may be done. Ile but ſtep up
Into Ram-Alley-Sanctuary, to Debtor,
That praies and watches there for a Protection;
And preſently return to you:—
Let it be ſo; ſlid the old angry man! Enter Brookeall.
He'll croſs us if he ſee us walke this way.
Theſe walks afford to miſerable man,
Undone by Suits, leave, yet, to ſit, or go,
Though in a ragged one; and look upon
The Giants, that over-threw him: Though they ſtrut Lawyers and others paſs over the Stage.
And are ſwolne bigger by his emptineſs.
Twas here, that we appointed, further meeting.
The two houres reſpited are almoſt run:
And he engag'd his honour in ſuch tearmes,
As I preſume he'll come. Honour! From whence
Can he derive that Princely attribute,
VVhoſe Father has deſcended to a Villany?
His houſe was Noble though: and this young man
Had a right virtuous Mother, whom I lov'd,
Intirely lov'd: and was in Competition
For marriage with her; when high Providence
Allotted her to him; who ſince her Death,
Defam'd my Siſter, and diſgrac'd our houſe.
My quarrell is not good againſt his Son
For that: But for my Boy! His doubtfull talk

Of him diſtracts me.
Enter Vermine, and Amphilus.
See the Vermine,
That hath devoured me living, His Aſpect
Addes to my Paſſion ſuch a bitterneſs,
That turnes me all to gal●. I muſt avoid him,
Introth Father-in-Law that ſhould ha' been, or that
May be yet (come, who knowes what luck we may have▪
Though the dancing Planets have cut croſs Capers over
Out heads.) I like this old fellows humour of chearing up
The heart well! And would I were loſt too, after my Mare,
My Dog and your Daughter: If this warm Sack has not
Kindled a deſire in me to play the good fellow, ſo it might
Be of free coſt, to drown theſe dry remembrances. Enter Valentine.
See, one of the jeerers. Is this he, that ſtole the marriage?
Yes, and perhaps my Daughter too. His Father's gone
Now, and I know not how to queſtion him.
Let me alone to queſtion him. Did you ſee this Gentleman's
Daughter, ſir, my Wife, that ſhould have been?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Since when, ſir.

lg.l: Since ſhe was ſtolne away, ſir. It were good
You would let us have her again; and quickly too,
Ere ſhe be worſe for wearing, as we ſay.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Old Brookall is not come yet.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: VVill you anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You are a buſy foole.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied. He knowes nothing.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You lye, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I think I do. You know nothing of her I mean, Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You lye again, Sir.

lg.l: I think I do again, Sir. Pray be not ſo terrible;
Examine him your ſelfe, if it pleaſe you.
VVere his eyes Baſiliskes; or did he beare
Upon his helliſh Countenance the faces
Of all the Furies (that no doubt attend him)
Ile ſhun no place for him. Are they acquainted?
O moſt prodigious!

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: VVhat do you know, Sir, of my Daughter, I be|ſeech you?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: That ſhe has a wretch, a miſerable Caitiff Unto her Father.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: How is that?—

lg.l: A villain that has ſcrap'd up by oppreſſion
Law-ſtrife and Perjury, a Dowry for her,
So mixt with curſes, that it would conſume
An Earles Eſtate to match with it and her.
And leave him curs'd in his Poſterity.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: How bleſt was J to miſs her!

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Can he ſpeak thus to him?

sp.speaker: Ʋer.
sp.p: Dar'ſt thou confront me thus?

lg.l: Dar'ſt thou yet keep a Groat of thine extorted Wealth,
And ſeeſt what Judgments fall one thee already?
Can all thy Gold redeem thy good opinion,
To thine owne Son? And though thou wouldſt no give
(In caſe he wanted it) to ſave his life,
A Hangmans Fee, much leſſe a Judges thanks,
Or price of a Lords Letter to reprieve him;
Yet may this Son ſurvive thee; and hourely he
Unto thy laſt houre, thine Affliction be.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O happy condition of a Batchelor!

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: I like this well in the young man▪—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How can you ſay you know this?

lg.l: Prethee how can't be otherwiſe?
Hadſt thou a vertuous Childe (as here and there,
Some Mothers win a ſoule) it would be taken
Dead or alive from thee▪ unto thy greife too,
To ſcape the curſe might come with a Childs part
Of thine ill-got eſtate: that's thy Daughters caſe.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Oh—

sp.speaker: Brro.
sp.p: Brave young fellow!

lg.l: But ſhew me where an evill Off-ſpring has not
Surviv'd to ſpurn the duſt of ſuch a Father;
And lewdly waſt in one or two deſcents
(Unto their own deſtruction) what was purchaſed
At price of ſoules departed?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Will you vouchſafe to leave me?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Pretty odd Doctrine, this!

lg.l: I have not done w' yee yet.
What corrupt Lawyer, or uſurious Citizen,
Oppreſſing Landlord, or unrighteous Judge,
But leaves the World with horror? and their wealth,
(By rapine forc'd from the oppreſſed Poor)
To Heires, that (having turnd their Sires to th' Devil)
Turne Idiots, Lunaticks, Prodigals, or Strumpets?
All wanting either wit, or will, to ſave
Their fatall Portions from the Gulfe of Law.
Pride, Ryot, Surfets, Dice, and Luxury,
Till Beggary, or diſeaſes turnes them after?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha' you done yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A word or two for uſe; and ſo an end.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Not ſo: It muſt be amplified a little further.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Torment and death! Is he come? Let me go▪

lg.l: Nay pray Sir heare them; though you pro|fit not;
I may perhaps. Methinks it edifies.
You ſayd, and you ſayd well; His tainted wealth,
Got by corruption, kept by niggardiſe,
Muſt flye as ill, through Luxury and Riot:
I add, that they who get it ſo, ſhall leave it,
To run at the like waſte, through their ſucceſſion
Even to the Worlds end: tis not one age,
Though ſpent in prayers, can expiate the wrong
Such an eſtate was gotten by, though the eſtate
Be, to a doyt, ſpent with it: But it ſhall
Fly like a fatall ſcourge, through hand to hand;
Through Age to Age, frighted by Orphans crys,
And Widows tears, the groanes and Lamentations,
Of oppreſſed Priſoners, mingled with the curſes
Of hunger-bitten Labourers, whoſe very ſweat
Thou robſt them of: this charming noiſe is up
Of many ſad, ſome mad afflicted wretches,
Whoſe marrow thou haſt ſuck'd; and from whoſe bowels,
The nouriſhment was cruſhd that fed thee, and
That ravenous Wolfe, thy conſcience.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I ſhall trounce you:

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: What's here? Worrying of Vermine?

lg.l: This noyſe, I ſay, of hideous cryes and curſes▪
That follows thine eſtate, will not be layd
In thy deare life time; nor in theirs, the ſtrangers,
That muſt be curs'd with the diviſion
Of it, when thou art gone: But, ſtill, it ſhall
Purſue, to all ſucceeding times, all thoſe,
That entertaine leaſt parcels of thy money,
When they ſhall finde at beſt, it can but buy
Diſgrace, diſeaſes, overthrows at Law,
And ſuch deare puniſhments; untill, at laſt,
All hands, affrighted with the touch of it,
Shall let it fall to earth; where it ſhall ſinke
And run into a veyne of Ore, ſhall reach—
To Hell. And they, that ſhall, hereafter, dig it,
Hundreds of Ages hence, muſt all compound
With the grand Lord o'th Soyle, the Devill, for't.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: So they make hot Purchaſes!

lg.l: Now Sir, you may inſtruct the Uſurer, to make uſe
Of all he has heard, while I avoyd his ſight;
Heaven knows I am ſick on't: you forget me Sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Feare not: I will not fayle you.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: No: Ile deliver him the uſe of all.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Oh the variety of my vexation—

lg.l: And all is this (as I advis'd before.)
Spend all your ſelfe, and ſave your Heires the ſin;
The ſhame, the ſorrows, and the puniſhments,
That are joynt-heritable with your wealth:
As very learnedly hath been related.
And there's the point, and the whole ſubſtance on't.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Beſtow your Subſtance ſo Sir, if you like it.

lg.l: Sir, my condition runs another way.
To the ſame end perhaps; following my Leader, here.
Your Son in Law? Truſt me, a moſt fine man:
And, if his life be anſwerable to his Doctrine,
Tis like heele lead you to a faire end of all.
Doubtleſſe he is a fine young Man indeed.
A proper teacher and an edifying.
Come Sir, lead on, I heare you are provided
Five hundred thick for this free nights adventure.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am Sir, here it is.

lg.l: I am ſo too Sir.
And here it is: And here it is, and here and there, and here it is.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O brave old man.

lg.l: Ile make one w'ye at your new Ordinary,
They ſay tis excellent.
For rarity and plenty,
There's no ſuch Penſion in all this City.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And all for nothing?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For leſſe then kiſſe your Hoſteſſe.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: And is there delicate Wine too? I muſt thither.

lg.l: The flowre of France, and quinteſſence of Spaine
Flow like a Spring-tyde through the Houſe.
O rare!
And all for nothing?
Hang nothing. Be it as twill,
I am for any thing; and as well provided,
As you, or any the beſt Gameſter there.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sir.

lg.l: I love to do theſe things. But firſt, pray tel me
Can you tell tale or tydings of his Daughter here?
Not of his Daughter: But I heard his Son
Was freed, this day, from Priſon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: How, how, how?

sp.speaker: Bro●.
sp.p: Yonder he is, ſtill▪ buſie.

lg.l: Ile among 'em. Walke you back a little,
And, get I any money, Ile lend thee ſome.
Ile tell you how. Some freind has paid his debt,
The Action is diſchargd; and he's releas▪d.
You practiſe my abuſe. Tis not in man,
To do me ſuch a miſcheife.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Away Girle.

lg.l: Thou art as hard, as this dry cruſt, here, was,
But he is better minded now, I hope:
Now, old man I am ſure thou art for me,
Thou curſedſt me before, but now thou wilt
Bleſſe me, I hope, and not without a Croſſe
Of a faire Silver Sixpence.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Hence you Harlot.

lg.l: Nay look you, if I could afford it, thinke you
I'de make two words w'ye: tis but a ſixpenny matter
Between us; why will you be ſo hard: tis but
So little leſſe left among all thy Children;
And Ile bate it them in their prayers for thee,
Though I be at the trouble, my ſelfe, to do it.
Troth, ſhe begs prettily. I muſt give her ſome|thing.
Here Wench.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: What is it, J will ſee it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Tis a good Shilling, and a vie; will you ſee't Sir?

sp.speaker: Bam.
sp.p: Look you, tis cover'd.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Gentlemen, will you come in? will you vie it?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No we deny it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You may revye it then, if you pleaſe. They come not in to binde it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Will you come in againe Sir?

lg.l: Sir, after you, and't be to my laſt ſixpence.
I will keep Covenant w'ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: A ſhilling more on that.

sp.speaker: Bum.
sp.p: Done Sir: there tis.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, theſe are Lads of bounty! Have you any minde yet Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: What, to be Bankrupts?

lg.l: Troth, thou wouldſt feare as much, ſhouldſt thou but break
Thy Porredge Pipkin.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Prithee what's thy name?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nell, my Mother calls me. J nere knew Sire, nor Godſire.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nell?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Yes: And tis as bonny a Beggars name, as ever came from beyond Trent.

lg.l: This Girle, methinks, howere neceſſitated
Into this courſe, declares ſhe has a ſpirit
Of no groſſe ayre: And J dare think her Blood,
Although, perhaps, of ſome unlawfull mixture,
Deriv'd from Noble veines. One may perceive
Much in her Language, in her Looks, and Geſture,
That pleads, methinks, a duty above pitty,
To take her from this way, wherein ſhe wanders
So farr from the intent of her Creation.
Your meaning is, you would buy her out of her Calling.
Is it not ſo?
Ten Peices J would give
Towards a new one for her.
Here's ten more
To bind you quite from begging. Can you afford it?
If yes, accept it. And let's ſee your back.
J make no Curtſies, nor ſend thanks that way.
No, Ile be forwards in them. May my thanks and prayers
Multiply years and bleſſings on your heads.
And when J beg againe, may Beadles take
Advantage on my back, and laſh the skin off,
So Heaven be ever with you—
Stay. Who would not have given this Money? Gentlemen,
Doſt not move you to give a packing penny?
Nor move you them for me. J ſhould, now, feare
One of their ill-got pence, here mingled, would
Corrupt and overthrow my righteous Fortune.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: O villanous Vixen.

lg.l: Each minute of this day augments my torment,
Yet I have coold it with ſome patience;
Attending Sir your anſwer.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: For your ſon.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: J have no Son. J aske you for my Daughter.

lg.l: Be this your pennance for your misbeleife,
Hye you to the Compter: if you finde not there
Your ſon; meet me an hour hence at my Fathers,
Ile tell you news of him; and he perhaps
May tell you of his Siſter. This deſerves
A fee. Your abſence pays it me. Go quickly,
We have ſome buſineſſe: And your ſtay will but
Make the Scene tedious.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Weel go. Wil't pleaſe you?

lg.l: Yes: we will off in Rhime. There is no doubt,
Jf Wat be not i'th Compter, he is out.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Now, what's the next vagary?

lg.l: Onely this Sir,
You have playd at ſmall Game with me. Now there is
A greater tryall of my Love and Bounty,
Inſtantly to be made. A Gentleman,
(J ſtay too long) an intimate Freind's arreſted,
But for two hundred pound on execution:
Will you joyne Charity to fetch him off?
J would 't had been thine owne caſe two dayes ſince.
One of your fine Companions, ſome poor Shark?
Ha, iſt not ſo?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Will you be pleasd to ſee him?

lg.l: J am halfe ſick of this Condition▪
J do begin, not altogether, now,
To love theſe things ſo well methinks. Humh ha!

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Nay, if you go not chearfully—

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Yes: J go.

lg.l: GOod Childe, thy tale is pittifull; yet it ſorts
So with the fell condition of my Fortune,
That J crave more of it.
J came not to
Diſcourſe of ſorrow, but to bring you comfort:
VVill you yet have a Crowne?
J prithee keep
Thy Money Child; and forwards with thy ſtory.
Thou ſaydſt thy Mother was a Gentlewoman.
Jle give you reaſon. Since J can remember,
Shee never did a wrong, though ſuffered much;
Nor the leaſt unjuſt thing▪ No, though her poverty
And care of me have pinch'd her very bowels,
Shee knew not how to ſeek anothers good,
So much as by requeſt. Shee never durſt borrow,
For feare to come ſo neer the danger of
A promiſe-breach: And, for baſe ends, to lye
Shee holds it ſacriledge. I faith ſhe jerk'd
That humour out of me; for J was given
(I tell you as a Freind) a little to't.
It came ſure by the Father▪ God forgive him.
Thou ſaydſt, thou thoughtſt, thy Father was a Knight.
How thinkſt thou he could lye then, to abuſe
A Virgine of that goodneſſe, as it ſeemes
Shee, that by him became thy Mother, was.
The Devill, ſure, was powerfull with him, then.
Nor do you hear me ſay, all Gentlefolkes
Are of one minde. Alaſſe they could not live
One by another then.
Peace, ſtay a little:
How came thy Mother to decline her ſpirit
So low, as thus to ſuffer thee to beg▪
Vertue goes often wet-ſhod, and is faine
To coble it ſelfe up to hold out water
And cold neceſſity: But ſure, the quality
Came to me by the Fathers ſide too: For
Tis a more commendable, and Courtly practiſe
To beg, then ſteale. He was perhaps, a Courtier.
J rather would be rob'd of all J have,
Then ſteale one farthing.
Thou ſay'ſt thy Mother never would reveale
To thee, or any one, her Birth, or Fortune.
Anſwer me, prethee, how doſt thou collect
Th' hadſt ſuch a Father? Or that he has thus
Wrong▪d thy poore Mother, by not marrying her?
Now you come to me indeed old man: How now,
What do you weep?
The ſharpneſs of the Aire
Strikes on mine eyes a little. Prethee ſay.
J firſt, as fain would know the hidden cauſe
That works this aptneſs in me, to diſcover
My Mother and my ſelfe to you, J know not
How to look off o' you. I ●aith you weep.
I have heard ſome talke of naturall inſtinct,
But know not what it is. Pray can you tell me?
Or any like reaſon, why J ſhould
Thus doat, and hang about you? Or tell me this,
Have you not been of better Fortune? Are not you
Some decayed Knight? Be not aſham'd, but tell me.
They cannot all be rich, there are ſo many.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Oh my heart!

lg.l: Yea, are your Conſcience ſtruck?
Have at you for a father then: And yet
Me-thinks you are more old in goodneſs, then
To be, ſo late, ſo wicked, as to wrong
A woman of her ſweetneſs. Yet Ile try you.
Here is a long-kept Paper. This is all
That ere I gathered of my Mothers wrong,
And of my Fathers cruelty, and condition.
It ſeemes this was his hand, and ruthfull farewell,
He turn'd her off withall. See, if you know it.
More then a thouſand times I have obſerv'd her
Weep o're that Paper; ever carefull, though,
Her teares might not deface it. If by chance,
As when thoſe teares prevented had her ſight,
Some ſoft ones did on that hard Sentence light,
Her Lips took off the Treſpaſs of her Eye;
And her hot Sighes reſtor'd the Paper dry.
Broo. This comes ſo neer a Miracle; that my faith
feare is ſtaggering. How got'ſt, thou this paper?
Phil. I ſtole it from my Mother, (and in Troth
〈…〉s all that ere I ſtole) becauſe ſhe ſhould not
Weep out her eyes upon't. I do not love,
〈…〉hough I am a beggar, to lead blind folks.
〈…〉o you not find there, that he is a Knight,
〈…〉ough he ſubſcribes no name? He tells her there,
〈…〉d tauntingly, he knowess ſhe is more ſorry
〈…〉 the loſt Ladyſhip he promis'd her▪
Then for her Maiden-head. Let me heare you read it.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Mine eyes, are now, too full indeed; I cannot.

lg.l: Are you the man then, whom I muſt ask bleſ|ſing?
If you bee, ſpeak. Ile have you to my Mother,
Though, I dare ſweare, ſhe had rather dye, then you,
Or any of your Race, or hers, ſhould ſee her,
Whilſt ſhe has breath. Yet I will undertake
To prattle you both good friends.
And you ſhall have my Mammy,
And ſhe ſhall have her Nell (that's J.)
The man ſhall have his Mare againe,
And all ſhall be well. How do you?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Prethee forbeare me good wench but a little▪

lg.l: I have kept my time you ſee; and ſhall not fail●
In any Circumſtance. Here are two Swords,
Pray take your choice. I have beſpoke a Boat
Shall land us o're the water, where you pleaſe;
Though, I Proteſt, I yet would beg your Love,
Next to my Naturall Fathers.
This I fear▪d.
And charg'd the plain way. But't ſhall not ſerve.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You took my part of late, againſt old Vermin●

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Prethee who would not? This is another caſe

lg.l: Why, if there be no remedy, pray accept
Your forty pounds. The money, Sir, may ſtead you
For your eſcape, when you have ta'ne my Life.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Your money 'wou'ld hang me, Sir. Your life not worth it.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Tis your own money; ſent you by your So●

lg.l: How know I that? Or that I have a Son
By thee unmurther'd.
I told you of a Letter I had miſlaid:
Look you. Do you know his hand?
If it be not,
Much chang'd, and lately, here is that wil match.
Was ever given Gold ſo weigh'd, and try'd?
What Lawyer, Nay, what Judge would be ſo ſcrupu|lous?
No want corrupts good Conſcience: Nor exceſs
Allaies in bad, the thirſt of Cov'touſneſs.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What do you think, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I think you beg again, and would be whipt.

lg.l: I fecks, I do not beg; but came to offer
This griev'd old man ſome of my infinite fortune
Found in your lucky money: Lucky indeed;
For I have found a Father by't. I vow
I think my Father. I'ſt not a fine old man?
I ſhall know more anon.
Her money, ſure,
Has made her Mad: How do you finde it, Sir?
My wonder now, is, how thou canſt be Son
Of ſuch a Father! Thou art honeſt ſure.
Here is your Sword, I will accept the money.
Then I ſhall live, and ſo may want the money.
Will you forbeare it for a day or two?
Your Sword again.
Now, I profeſs to you, I have preſent need on't,
And am as ſtrict, Sir, for my right, as I
Before was to decline it.
Pray, Sir, take it;
And give me leave to beg your charitable
Conſtruction of my Father.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: How is that?

lg.l: Did you but know the care, the coſt, and tra|vell
He has been at a thouſand waies, to finde
Your injur'd Siſter, to make good his fault,
If poſſibly he might—

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: O fie, O fie!

lg.l: Till all Opinion gave her dead; and then
The meanes he has ſought to do you Offices
Againſt your knowledge. For he knew your Spirit
Would not except of his benevolence.—

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Read that, and gueſſe whoſe deed 'tis. Stand off Girle.

lg.l: Yes forſooth Father, I ſhall learn in time,
Ile call him Father till he findes me another.
J know he could not ſhed thoſe teares for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: But does ſhe live, to whom this was directed?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Speak low▪ is that your Fathers hand?

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Along with me then. Girle, lead you the way.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Anan forſooth Father▪

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Shew us to your Mother.

lg.l: Shall he go too? What will the Neighbours think?
There's none but Beggars all about us. Ods ſo,
There'll be a ſhow indeed.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: No matter. Will you go?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir, they will hale you to peeces.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: Will you deny me?

lg.l: How ſhall I anſwer'● to my Mother? She
Never ſaw man, nor has been ſeen by man,
That J k〈…〉n my life.

sp.speaker: Ʋal.
sp.p: N〈…〉tter: Will you on?

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Ile ſave thee blameleſſe.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Troth Ile venter.—

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: Frances, Magdalen, Jane, Alice. Wine on a Table.

lg.l: You are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Good lack! And is it you, Mrs. Alice? I'ſt poſſible? Are you come to learn Carriage too? I will make bold with tother Glaſſe of Wine. At a word, J like your French Carriage the better, that it allowes elder Women to drink VVine.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: They have no other drink, except water. And Maids are▪ allowed but that.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And young wives (they ſay) wine with their water.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Mingle your Glaſſe, then, Daughter. This for me. Your father has ſo fought you Mrs. Alice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My Father has miſt us too, by this time▪

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: But neither of 'em can dream French enough, to direct 'em hither, J warrant you. And does ſhe learn the Carriages very well, Madam|ſilly?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Madamoyſelle, ſi vous plaiſt.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: What do yee cal't? I ſhall never hit it. ▪How do you finde your Schollar?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O, ſhe is very good. She learn very well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p:
But how much carriage hath ſhe learnt? Heark
you Mrs. Alice. Have you not learnt to carry a man? Has not a good Husband ſtolne you hither?
J can think waggi●hly I tell you: And an old Ape has an old eye. Go to.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No ſuch matter, Mrs. Bumpſey.

sp.speaker: Fra:
sp.p: VVhat is that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I ask you how much carriage she has learnt?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: She come but dis day; And she carry both the hands already.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: How ſay by that. I'ſt poſſible? Can she carry both her hands in one day?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yes, and before to morrow, she shall carry the foot as well.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: It ſeems, then, you teach handling before footing in your French way.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You may learn dat of de leetle Shild. De lee|tle Shild you ſee will handle de ting, before it can ſet one foot to de ground. Come, let me ſee you make a Reverance.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Reverance! VVhat's that?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Tis dat you call a Curtſie. Let me ſee you make Curtſie.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Look you heare then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O fee, fee—dat is de groſs english Douck, for de ſwagbuttock'd-wife of de Peſant.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: How like you this then? There's a Reverence I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Fee, dat is worſe. See how you carry de hands like de Comedien dat act de shangling.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Shall I ever hit on't troe? I muſt take tother Glaſs.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Take heed she does not take too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I hope she will not. But there's no croſſing her.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Let me ſee your hands.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: There they bee. They have been a little too fa|miliar with Sea-coale fires, and much other courſe houſwifry, which J ſhall utterly abhor, and waſh off, when J have learnt to carry them Courtly.
But ſhall J ever do it, think you?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and all your other parts and mem|bers.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I may winne my Husband to love mee Court|ly then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: To love, and lye with you Courtly.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: That's but ſeldome, I doubt.

lg.l: You shall know all de waies to winne his Love,
Or any mans, to multiply your honour.—

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: J will ſo multiply then.

lg.l: Not onely in your looks, your ſmiles and ſweet Careſſes▪
(Beſides the help of Painting) that adorn
The face: But with the motion of each Lineament,
Of the whole frame of your wel order'd body.
An Eye, a Lip, a finger shall not move;
A Toe trip unregarded. But your Geat
And your whole gracefull Preſence shall attract,
(Beyond affection) admiration:
As Ile artifice you.
Ile be a Nimph. Diana and her Dearlings▪ deare, deare, deare, &c. ſing.
But may I paint, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: O moſt allowably; nay, commendably.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Tother Glaſs for that.

lg.l: Then for the Art of dreſſing, ſetting forrh
Head Face, Neck, Breaſt,; with which I will inſpire you.
To cover, or diſcover any part—
Unto de beſt advantage.
That is to ſay,
To hide shame, or shew all: that's her meaning.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You shall have no defect perceiv'd, no grace conceal'd.

lg.l: I am for the naked Neck and Shoulders, then.
For (I tell you Miſtreſs) I have a white Skin,
And a round ſtreight Neck: ſmooth and plump Shoul|ders,
Free from French Flea-bits, and never a wrinckle
Neare'em, though I ſay't.
'Thas been ſuggeſted by invective men,
Women, to juſtiſie themſelves that way,
Began that Fashion. As one tother ſide,
The fashion of mens Brow-looks was perhaps
Devis'd out of neceſſity, to hide
All il-grac'd forehead; Or beſprinckled with
The outward Symptomes of ſome inward griefe.
As, formerly the Saffron-ſteeped Linnen,
By ſome great man found uſefull againſt Vermine,
Was ta▪ne up for a fashionable wearing.
Some Lord that was no Niggard of his Beauty,
Might bring up narrow brims to publish it.
Another, to obſcure his, or perhaps
To hide defects thereof, might bring up broad ones.
As queſtionleſs, the ſtreight, neat timber'd Leg,
Firſt wore the Troncks, and long Silk-ho●e: As likely
The Baker-knees, or ſome ſtrange shamble shanks,
Begat the Ancle-breeches.
Sur● the men
Took that conceit from us. What woman shewe●
A Leg▪ that's not a good one?—
Theſe among men, are followed for the fashions,
That were invented for the better grace.
(As our Attires) to ſet off Limb, or face.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Good lack! What knowledge comes from forraigne parts?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: I prethee Wat, have patience for an houre.

lg.l: Not for a minute, Sir, Ile not be kick'd,
And call'd baſe Pandar for your baſeneſs.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Nay, look you Wat.

lg.l: And had almoſt been pump'd,
And made a ſport for Water-men i'th' Thames.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: But Heare me, Wat.

lg.l: Ile heare my Father ſooner. (Give me hence
My Siſter) were he a ravenous Beaſt, a Wolfe,
J would obey him rather then trudge a foot
Further in your baſe way. Heart J am hip-ſhot.
Now, would his Bodies paines convert his Soule,
Twere a good work.
J am in deſperate feare
O'th' Mourning of the Chine too with the kicks▪
And hunches they o're-laid me with. O baſe!
Without reſiſtance. Give me hence my Siſter.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: But how was it my fault?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Was't not your project?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What may this mean▪

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: No harm J warrant you.

lg.l: Nay, it ſhall out. Your baſe inhumane Pro|ject,
To ſell your Daughters Maiden-head. (J care not
Who heares me, J.) And cunningly to make me
Your Hackney-jade to fetch your Chapmen in.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Where are we now?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: What did my Husband mean to wiſh us hither?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Baſeneſs! J cannot call it bad enough.

lg.l: You were as forward in it as my ſelfe,
And wooed me you might have her without all faults.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Mine eyes are opened now.

lg.l: But J beleive,
They were almoſt beaten out firſt.
And J vow
Ere J will marry ſo, Ile take a Beggar,
And joyn in trade with her, though I get nothing
But—My name is Vermine already, J
Thank a good Father for't.
A Beggar-wenches breed would propagate
Your name moſt numerouſly.
Much better then your Sale-ware, and more laſting.
J think J ſaw her to day muſt be the woman,
Good Madame Polcat, the trim Schoole-miſtriſs.
Ile make bold with your Schollar. What! you have more.
Ile carry her and her Virginity
Unto ſome fitter place of Execution.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: You brought me hither, Sir, and here Ile ſtay.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: What! in a Bawdy-houſe?

lg.l: O deare! and is it ſo? VVhat are we then?
Is this your boun faſhion? Is this the carriage of the
Body, that you would teach us? What, to bee
VVhores? VVe could learn that at home, and
there were need, without your teaching,

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Mother; what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Mrs Bumpſey; pray feare no harm.

lg.l: O good lack! what will become of us? where
are we now, Jane?
Betray'd! betray'd! Our honours are betray'd. O my
poor Bump. how will thou take this at my hands,
though J carry them never ſo Courtly?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p:
'Sfoot, ſhe's in her Mawdlin fit: All her wine
ſhowres out in teares.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh,—

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Pray have her in. Look carefully to her,

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh,—

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Take the Bottle with yee.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: In all to the next Room.—

div.stage: Exeunt Fra. Jane leading out Magda|len.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Sir, ſhe ſhall with me. Ile leave her where J found her.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Sir, no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, Gentlewoman, muſt I kick you out o▪ doores?

lg.l: No, nor depart your ſelfe, but by Authority.
J am provided for you. Friends come in. Enter two Sergeants.
And do your Office.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: We arreſt you, Sir; Nay, we ſhall rule you▪

lg.l: Ha, ha, ha. VVhy, this is well, and very hoſ|pitably done.
VVould any man but an old Bawde ha' done this?
Sir, J miſtruſted your Apoſtacy.
Since you revolt, J muſt recall my money;
Or lay you where J found you, as you threatned your Siſter here.
Baſer, and baſer ſtill. Are you a Knight?
A Knight, a Poſt-Knight. A Poſtillion,
That rides a fore-horſe, o▪re the Eares in durt,
Three fingers thick, is not ſo baſe. You Varlets,
Do you arreſt folkes in a bawdy-houſe?
VVe do not finde it ſo; Or, if it be,
The place may be as honeſt as our Office.
VVill you walk, Sir?
Stay; Let me conſider,
If now my Father (as ſome in like caſes
Have done) would take a fine ſubmiſſion.
I could affoard to kneele and whine, me-thinks,
Rather then back to my old Ward again.
Twill nere be handſome though.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The buſineſs Gentlemen.

lg.l: My lucky friend.
Sir, you reliev'd me lately. Could you now
But add another Favour, it might teach
One, that nere learnt to pray, to pray for you.
Do you not know me, Sir? Twas I you ſav'd
Out of the Temple Sudds.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Haſt thou been ſhav'd ſince?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No, Sir, I was diſguis'd.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Diſguis'd!

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Diſguis'd in villany, which I recant.

lg.l: Who knowes but he may prove an honeſt man?
Pray, Sir, a word.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: We do not uſe to wait dry-fiſted; nor dry throa|ted.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I would you were as wet all over, as I was like to have been: Or, as you are Catchpoles, I would you had been but in thoſe hands I eſ|cap'd from.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: You have prevail'd, Sir.

lg.l: Sergeants you ſhall not out of the Houſe. Here's for halfe an houres attendance. Go into that Room with your Priſoner. You ſhall have Wine, and Smoak too.
Be of good cheere friend▪ if thou canſt be honeſt,
I can relieve thee: feare not.
Sir, get my Father but to ſay as much,
And you ſhall be Co-heire with me. I vow you ſhall have halfe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: VVee'll talk anon. The Youth appeares con|verted.

lg.l: There was no other meanes to work it by,
But that I us'd; to urg'd him paſt his Nature.
He was ſo free in's Villany, that I
Giving the Spurs, ran him beyond his ſpeed;
Quite off his Legs, and glad to be led home.
His Father comes on fairely: I have follow'd
All your Inſtructions concerning him,
And my fantaſtick Father-'Law. Both whom
Are hard at hand, with the wiſe weſtern Knight.
He too's content to go to the beſt Ordinary,
VVhile tis beſt cheap he ſaies. VVhere are the women?
Your Mother-'Law, after ſhe had got
As much French Carriage, as might ſerve to furniſh
A petty Court; is fallen into a fit,
To over-throw it all againe.
The better.
But is the houſe cleare, Sir, of all your Riflers?
As I could wish; And well ſatisfied.
For, when they underſtood the honeſt end,
My Project aim'd at; which, by an Oration
VVell charg'd with virtuous Sentences, I forc'd
Into the nobler Breaſts: they all recanted
The barbarous purpoſe; and as freely left
Their money for that Charitable uſe,
To which I pre-intended it. The reſt
Purs'd theirs again. But yet I have collected
In this odd uncouth way, five hundred Pounds,
That was laid down at ſtake for a Virginity,
To make an honeſt ſtock for Franck.
Tis good.
I may fetch in my Gueſts in the mean time
You maybe pleas'd, Sir, to peruſe this Baper.
How now! what's here? How might he come by this?
It is the ſcorn I ſent my injur'd Love;
My abus'd Elynor: The hand, that threw
Her from me. O, that at the price of it
I could receive her.
Sir, by your leave,
VVe come to ſup w'yee. Does your Rifling hold?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: VVhat, you are off o'the hooks, me-thinks.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: If there be no ſuch thing, tell us the Riddle?

lg.l: You ſhall know all, and briefely. Franck, come in. Enter Franck.
Now Gentlemen—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Let us ſalute her firſt.—

lg.l: She does not taſt of ſin. Faire Chaſtity
Sits crown'd upon her Brow, with an aſpect,
May beat down. Luſt to Hell, from whence it roſe.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: You profeſſe Nobly, ſir.

lg.l: I vow, and do not lye to you: If I finde
Your Father ſo inhumane, you againſt it:
VVee'll be your Reſcue, if forty able ſword-men
VVhich we have, at the ſignall of a finger,
Planted in readineſs, can fetch you off:
Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Yes, and admire your goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Now we are for you, ſir:

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p:
Then heare the ſtory; which your late Im|patience
would not permit.

lg.l: You ſpeak not now
In that high Phraſe, or tone, as you Enter Valentine. Bumpſey, Ver|mine, Amphilus, Brookall, Elynor, Phillis.
did then. Val. Stand here, unſeene;
and heare attentively.
I am a Gentleman, that by foule miſdeed
(Heaven, Heaven I aske thee pardon) once did wrong
To an unfortunate Family, by rejecting,
After affiance, and her love abuſ▪d,
A Gentlewoman—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: You got with child, and then deny'd her Marriage.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Twas ſo.

sp.speaker: Ely.
sp.p: Ay me!

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No paſſion, gentle Soule.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If this ſhould prove my Father now!—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Well Sir, your Gentlewoman!

lg.l: Shee, on the diſcontent, (poore hapleſſe Soule)
Now foureteen Winters ſince though ſadly burden'd,
Fled, and no more is heard of: at the firſt
My wildneſſe took no ſenſe of this deare Loſſe;
But drew me through the wayes of careleſſe pleaſure,
By riotous expence, that mine eſtate
And Credit ran at waſte, and was nigh ſpent,
Untill my treſpaſſe cry'd againſt my Conſcience
To render ſatisfaction: but in vaine
We offer to the dead. My Genius therefore
Prompts me to gratefull deeds unto her Blood.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: What can this come to?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Shee had a Brother, that loſt his eſtate By Law—

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.p: Means he not mee?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: To a Corrupt Oppreſſor—

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Ha! How's that?

lg.l: Was ſtript out of the very Coat he wore,
Had nothing left him, but a Sonne—

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: What's all this to your Daughter?

lg.l: Even all that may be; (ſee) His Sonne's my Daughter. Diſcover Fran●.
Now do you find my project Gentlemen?
It has at Charge of three dayes Houſe-keeping
Put hal●e a thouſand pounds in's purſe; Beſides
A faire pull for his Fathers Land againe:
For he has, by a lawfull Church-man, married
The Daughter of his Fathers Adverſary.

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Why, here are wonders!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Bravely, nobly done

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: Come Mrs. Alice; and juſtifie your Act.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: My Daughter, ha!

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: My ſweetheart, hoe!

lg.l: Your haes and hoes can not draw her from me,
Thee is my Wife.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: By what witch-craft?

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: By ſtronger Charmes, then your Art can diſ|ſolve▪ You know me now, Sir—And my Project, do you not?

sp.speaker: Ol.
sp.p: Amb. Sir Humfrey Dryground.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: I am ſtruck dum with wonder.

sp.speaker: Elin.
sp.p: O tis he, tis hee.

lg.l: Alaſſe ſhe ſwounes, Sir cheare you up this Lady,
While I appeaſe the reſt. A word with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: I will not be appeaſ'd.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: My love! my Elynor!

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p:
So, cheare her up Sir Humfry. To her againe Sir Humfry; your Sonne and mine in Law has told me all your ſtory, and reconcil'd your Brother Brookall to you before your interview. I know all, the full point and the whole ſubſtance; the flat and plaine of the buſineſſe; and now I love theſe things againe. How now Sir Am|philus?
Drown'd in Melancholly?

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: No: But and I were at the Duckingpond, I know what I know. But when I drown my ſelfe, I'll give you leave to hang me.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Your pardon, and your bleſſing; I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Hence.

lg.l: Was this thy Journey into France my Boy?
High Providence hath made it good. But tell mee,
Was Love your chiefe Inſtructor to this Marriage?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Indeed it was equall in her and mee.

sp.speaker: Ali.
sp.p: Pray Sir your bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Away.

sp.speaker: Broo.
sp.p: Turne this way for a bleſſing then my Daughter,

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Shall I tell you Neighbour? Law has no re|liefe for you; And Conſcience and you have a longe time been ſtrangers▪ Could you be friends and embrace Conſcience now, all would be well. And there's the ſubſtance. Is it plaine?

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Conſcience! do you know where ſhe is?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Heeres one has brought her in his true Conver|ſion.

lg.l: Sir, If you can forgive, and can obey you▪—
I now can better kneele▪ then ſpeak
Do you note thoſe teares, Sir? Had you loſt your Daughter,
My Father had in this made you amends,
In finding you a Son. His Art converted him.

sp.speaker: Ver.
sp.p: Sure, all's but Apparition, or a dream.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Ha! Think you ſo? Tis your own fleſh and blood: And by your leave and liking▪ may prove as ho|neſt a Man, as his Father. Is not this plaine now? For|give and bleſſe ●m all over, and ſo Kiſſe 'em too▪ They are your Children▪

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: O my deare Bump! Art thou there? Thou mayſt kiſſe, and forgive me all over too, for any harm, or diſhoneſty; though the place be as they ſay-at a word, Bump. Thou mayſt be|leive me, I came but to learn Carriage of the Body, nor to carry no bodies body, but my owne body, Bump. No truely, truely Bump. o—o—that ever I did that.

sp.speaker: Bump.
sp.p: Peace, peace: All's well. At leaſt I know your Diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Mag.
sp.p: Think me not drunk, good Bump, a little faſhion-ſick, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Amp.
sp.p: Faſhion-ſick! a fine civill word. To be drunk, is faſhion-ſick.

lg.l: I am awak'd out of the Lethargy
Of Avarice: Bleſt may our Friendſhip be.
I will not ſleep, before the holy Prieſt
Has done the Office. Bleſſing on my Girle.
Val, Thou haſt made me young againe: the beſt
Occurrents in this Project have been thine.
Thy Accidents exceeded my deſigne.
They do not yet ceaſe here: For ſee, the ſtrife
Betwixt theſe long continued Adverſaries
Perfectly reconcil'd; and both have given
The young and hopefull married paire their Bleſſings.
To which I have given my Conſent moſt freely.
For it was Nolens volens as they ſay.
They are beholden to you. Mr. Vermine
Reſtores unto the Son the Fathers Land,
For Dowry with his Daughter: And is taken
So with the good you wrought upon his Son,
The Convertite here; that if he ſtand firme
Till the determination of your Mortgage,
Hee ● cancell it, and ſend it Gratis to you.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: That's ſure enough. But Sir, the other buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: What's that?

lg.l: The moſt to be admir'd of all;
He loves my Siſter here; and has done long:
But, now, that he perceaves her worth (being yours)
And, ſince you promiſ'd him your Daughter too,
He makes it his faire ſuit.
I'll talk with his Father.
And Wat ſtand you but firme, and live reform'd,
Winning my Daughters love, you ſhall have mine.
That Fortune is not blinde, that ſhew'd me way
To Father, Friends, and Husband in one day.

sp.speaker: Dry.
sp.p: This binds us all into a Brother-hood.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.p: And with a Brothers Love I now ſalute you.

lg.l: So may we with a generall embrace,
Create the Heart of Friendſhip, not the Face.
Come Gentlemen, your Ordinary ſtayes,
Twill prove good fare (I hope) though no rich Feaſt;
And acceptable to each welcome Gueſt.
NO way ambitious yet of vulgar praiſe,
The writer of theſe Scenes deſires to know,
By your faire leave, though he aſſume no Bayes,
Whether he pull'd faire for a ●●afe or no.
If yes, then let your hands aſſiſtant be,
T'incourage him to climb Apollo's tree.
